I saw this movie the first time by coincidence and it became my favourite movie.The life of a hit-man is changed when he opens the door to a 12-year old girl whose family was killed by a group of corrupted DEA Agents.Léon and Mathilda's friendship becomes very close - they enter in each other lives : what Léon does involves Mathilda and what Mathilda does involves Léon.She wants to get revenge, especially because they killed her 3-year old brother and she knows that Léon is the one for this task. The end is not the one she predicted though.Jean Reno was brilliant, no-one could have done better. Same story for Natalie Portman - she had a tough role but did a great job using her incredible style.Finally, the soundtrack is brilliant and this makes the movie absolutely perfect : 10/10.

I went and saw this movie at the cinema several years ago knowing -nothing- about it and was (almost literally) blown away by it.While it started out to be a fairly standard thriller, it quickly turned into a very original, very intense and ultimately deeply moving character piece intertwined with some grip-the-edge-of-your-seat action sequences, heightened no doubt by the fact that you -cared- about these characters and what happened to them.Jean Reno in many ways reprises his walk-on part as Victor the "cleaner" from Beson's "La Femme Nikita" (Leon/The Professional could almost be a sequel) and does so wonderfully, but the most enchanting surprise was then-newcomer Natalie Portman's Mathilda. I hadn't (and still haven't) been this impressed by a child's performance since, well, ever. I'm very glad to see that she has further delivered on her acting promise in movies such as Beautiful Girls and found a deserved measure of commercial success in Phantom Menace (Portman was one of the few redeeming features of that particular movie, but that's another review).The only slight flaw I perceived at the time was Gary Oldman's performance which, while effective, was - I thought - somewhat over-acted. Little did I know the measure of Oldman's restraint in this film until I saw his turn in The Fifth Element.

reviews.review_title: Perfect synthesis of European and American cinema
reviews.content: This story about the friendship between a professional "cleaner" and a 12-year-old girl whose family has been killed by a gang of drug cops is one of the few movies that get better and better the more often I watch them. Luc Besson's masterpiece has everything a good movie needs: Thrill, excellent timing and cinematography, a touch of romance and, above all, outstanding actors. Jean Reno, between coolness and melancholy, acts brilliantly as the killer (a profession that he already performed in "La femme Nikita"). And Natalie Portman, this hugely talented (and beautiful) young actress, maybe the best in her generation, is stunning in her (one can hardly believe it) first appearance on the screen. Everyone who is a fan of this movie (or wants to become one) should watch the "Director's Cut" as this longer version gives the relationship between Léon and Matilda more depth and emphasis. All in all, "Léon" is a perfect synthesis of European and American cinema  a modern thriller classic.  10/10

Tall Frenchman Jean Reno excels with minimalist mimicry, impressive physicality and a tenderness in the title role of Luc Besson's powerfully, excitingly and suspensefully directed crime thriller drama about a lonesome hitman in New York, who accidentally gets homeless girl Natalie Portman, whose family was wiped out by corrupt detective Gary Oldman, and befriends himself with her, set for a tragedy. Despite the film's unbelievable central premise, Besson works at the top of his filmmaking skills here, especially in the gloriously, excellently choreographed action scenes, which mark the high points of the film along with the terrific cast. Portman is outstanding in her debut, although her role is badly written, she comes off very well, while Oldman plays the wickedly funny nutcase bad guy with gusto, and with Danny Aiello perfectly cast as Léon's only friend, boss and teacher. The music by Eric Serra and Sting is superb.

reviews.review_title: A hitman becomes very close friends with a 12-year-old girl whose family has been murdered by DEA-agents.
reviews.content: I like suspense and this film is one hell of a thriller! I was also charmed by the friendship that grew between the hitman and the little girl. It shows that even the coldest persons do have a weak spot. These two characters -Leon and Mathilda- really are each others opposites. The opposites between characters makes the entire story. Stan (the DEA-agent) is as cruel as the hitman, but he's bad to the bone. Leon isn't, he's got a hart. Luc Besson -whose films I appreciate very much- really made one of his best films with "Leon". Gary Oldman plays one of his mean characters again, and again he does it brilliantly. The look on his face makes me shiver!! This film was the subject of a paper I made last year for one of the classes I took at university. The professor asked me to name a few "symbols" that are used in the film and to comment on them. I named the plant and the sunglasses as the most important symbols. Think about it!!!

This is a great film about how love smashes through man-made boundaries. Unconditional love and lust.
But the disc omits some scenes I clearly remember watching! There are no sexual extras as a bonus scene or whatever... Don't know what else to say.
Always on top of it. Reno is a unique talent and face, someone you never forget.

The first time I saw this movie I was blown away.  Then I saw the extended directors cut and I was hooked.  Everything was perfect, the music, setting, and of course the cast.  Jean Reno was the perfect choice as the cleaner. I couldn't imagine anyone else taking the role.  Gary Oldman was in good form as always (to really see him in a crazy role see True Romance).  I give it a 10/10.

One of the better I've seen.  Brilliant acting, brilliant storyline, brilliant action.  This movie deserves a higher rating, in my opinion. There's something for everyone here - action buffs and romance lovers alike.If you've never seen it, rent away.  9/10

Just watch it, can't embellish on already excellent reviews! Only discovered Director's cut and watched for first time two weeks ago, seen it 5 times already. Acting & relationships truly amazing, particularly Leon and Mathilda.Camera work? Outstanding, as is music selection.In my all time top 10.My cat wants to know if the cat in Danny Aiello's restaurant got a casting credit. If so, rating moves to 10.

One of the best romantic action films ever. Script and direction are fantastic. Focusing in various tiny areas of a relationship that does not care what society and mainstream think is making the movie perfect.

One of best movie ever from top to bottom
actor,director,writer....
what ever you thinks is right in good way about this movie.

reviews.review_title: The Assassin with a Heart of Gold
reviews.content: Typical of the 1990's tripe coming from Hollywood to convince viewers that, if you look heard enough, you'll find an assassin with a heart of gold. (A similar "heart of gold" theme is repeated with a prostitute in "Pretty Woman", and with a stripper in "Independence Day".)Yet, I give it a six because of Natalie Portman's outstanding acting debut and Gary Oldman's convincing performance.

A wonderful film with subtle undertones that are more expressive in the version of the film Luc Besson wanted to be distributed,with an extra 26 minutes of footage. All of Luc Bessons work is done in such visual splendour and this is no exception. Fine performance throughout, especially the young Natalie Portman, and superb direction, make this a film hard to forget.

A bad guy to cheer for. An innocent 12 year old girl you hope survives long enough to kill the bad guys. The "Badder" (sic) guys were real scum. A sleeper. Like a good book, I started watching and couldn't change the channel. An entertaining 2 hours.

This is the fourth best film ever, behind a film I won't mention for fear of people not taking me seriously, Schindler's List, and Star Wars.  I advise everbody who has a chance to watch it, to do so.  They air it on USA a lot so you you could probably check it out there.  But on USA they refer to it by it's american title, The Professional.

Léon is a masterpiece, a modern classic. And it´s also filled with religious symbolism, such as when Léon opens the door for Mathilda and she enters his apartment, you don´t have to look very hard to see the "light of salvation" coming out of the apartment covering Mathilda. This movie is one of my favorites, and the acting is one such a high level that it´s almost scary. Gary Oldman, and Jean Reno delivers their best performances to this day. And the hugely talented Natalie Portman acts with the vulnerability and sensitivity of an actress filled with routine, although she was but 13 years old at the time she acted in this masterpiece. This movie is well written, it has a beautifully painful cinematography, it´s amazingly good directed, it´s extremely well acted, and the music is so beautiful. I do not think there exists a person who hasn´t been touched be this violent, touching and beautiful film. A true masterpiece.   10/10

First things first: twelve-year-old Matilda (Natalie Portman) provocatively singing "like a virgin" for her hitman father-figure (Jean Reno) is extremely discomforting to watch, as it dances to the precipice of the ultimate taboo, bringing itself back just in the nick of time. The remainder of the film, despite its plot, tells an amazing story about human connections, with newcomer Portman toying with a brilliant, experienced cast.This is one of the best films ever made, and perhaps the best film debut ever. The relationship which is explored is not between Matilda and Leon, but rather Portman and the camera. Her later work is solid but topping this is something few, including her, could ever accomplish. How it didn't sweep the Oscars is beyond me.

I just saw the DVD international uncut version of this movie, and it was 10 better than the US release version. The 24 cut minutes make this a completely different movie. I had seen this movie back in 1994 at the theater, and then seen it many other times on home video. I feel that I was robbed, after watching this version. The extra 24 minutes show more of the relationship between Leon and Matilda. It also shows more of the training that she goes through. This really helps me understand the ending a lot better. If you are a fan of this movie or are looking for a good movie to watch make sure to check out this version it is well worth it.

This is one of those VERY rare movies, that even though you may have seen it for the first time on cable TV, when it is again aired, you still end-up watching it again, and again.  ("The Shawshank Redemption" comes to mind as being such a movie.)  For each time I watch this movie, I seem to aquire a deeper attatchment to the story, and become more involed in the personal stuggle's of the two main characters; Jean Reno as the "professional hitman", and Natalie Portman as "the little girl".As one reviewer so accuratly put it, "A man with nothing to lose, and a girl who has lost everything."  From there, comes a true masterpiece of a film. Natalie Portman gave a brilliant performance as the little girl, and IMO, was cheated out of an Oscar nomination.  For she really "shined" in such a demanding role, and at even such a young age.From the surface, the movie might seem like it would be a typical "hitman, violent movie".  But it is FAR from it.  From the beginning, to it's thought-provoking end, it will leave you wanting more.  And after you see it, you will understand why it made the "Top 250 movie list" of all time,(currently #64), being voted-in by the ones who REALLY count, "ordinary people".This movie has been be added to my small, and very selective, DVD collection...as I believe it is a worthy addition to any DVD collection.

The DC cut completely ruins the original cut in my humble opinion. It adds questionable (to say the least) material with some additional never ending "house picking" action.Buy the cinema cut, one of the worst director cuts in movie history ... it is so bad, dunno if the original version can restore "faith" back. I 'm surprised they let him film these scenes to be honest ... the flow/pacing issues the DC has is not the worst offender. The theatrical cut was about a little girl and an adult guardian, so to speak a The Bodyguard mit a 14y old. The director cut is an homage to Woody Allen's Marriage ...Do not buy! Not just because of these scenes, but because of the terrible pacing they produce without any merit (it makes sense he left them out for the cinema version).Theatrical cut = must watch Director cut = probably the worst director cut to ever come out ...

Being a fan of La Femme style films - just the flavor of a film like, well recently  The Bourne ID - I expected to either find a home in this, or reject it after inflated expectations.   I had read your reviews.  So I gave it 9/10 for the consistent style and for Natalie's unbelievable acting performance.   Even those who fault the movie for the actions scenes or other reasons STILL unclear to me, these people must admit that for a 13 yr old actor (playing 12) we are seeing something truly exceptional.  I could imagine the other characters having been played successfully by other actors, but I cannot imagine a better performance from anyone in modern cinema for Matilda.  Brava Natalie!!  The reviewers slamming Natalie Portman in this movie are harboring some ill, completely blinding them.

This movie is also shown on American TV as "The Professional."As the previous reviewer stated, it has awesome performances by Jean Reno, Gary Oldman, and an unknown child actress named Natalie Portman. Reno's character is successful as an assassin mostly because he is so dysfunctional as a human being.  Which is also why Oldman's character is so successful as a whacked-out corrupt cop.  It takes Portman's transition form an innocent child, unaware of her parents' drug dealing, to a determined young woman to bring both Reno and Oldman a sense of humanity that is eventually their undoing.This is a great movie with excellent acting, exciting, realistic action, and a neat plot.  It shows Portman definitely as "an actress to watch in the future," and of the "whacked-out" villain roles by Oldman, this is probably the best.

reviews.review_title: Wouldn't wish for something better than this.
reviews.content: The scandal here for most viewers is the fact that they used a 12-year old girl to indulge in a script filled with mature content and engaging intimate advances to a man years older than her. But even with that, Natalie Portman still did deliver a performance; raw, character, angst.

The carachter of leon is really great. Although he's a killer he has his own principles, that human inside him is, somehow, still alive.
I liked his relationship with matelda so much. It was my first time seeing a love story in a foreign movie that doesn't revolve around sex. I appreciated leon so much when he refused. At the beginning and may be till now I can't accept the idea of this relation beacuse of the age gap between them, but really I can't deny its beauty!
And maybe it's like what matelda said "you see leon? Nothing can stop love"..

There are movies that shouldn't be graded, because you can do it in only one way. Tha classic. Usually one lacks in words of description and praise. Therefore, only few words about 'Leon.' I've seen it for the second time recently, so I didn't have to pay all my attention to perfectly constructed plot and I could enjoy tasting many other things. Mainly the music. It pervaded me, I almost got high. Gorgeous. I can't find any words to describe it. Viva Eris Serra! And finely interspersed Bjork and Sting.The cinematography may be not terrific, but combined with editing which makes a specific mood it creates true masterpiece.Perfect ratio between comedy, drama and action. Splendid acting. I go into raptures!

There is not a single part of this film that I dislike. The acting, especially form Natalie Portman, is fantastic. The story feels real, and draws you in throughout. The ending to this movie is probably one of, if not, my favourite movie endings of all time, with the amazing shootout and the emotional climax to the story. Some people may feel uncomfortable towards certain scenes, but to me that is the point of those scenes, to paint Leon in a light where he doesn't see Mathilda in the way she sees him: He sees her as a thing he must protect.Overall, well worth the watch if you haven't seen it already
Lovers making their own way in this world.No requirement for acceptance from anybodyJust asking for each other's embrace and completely accepting of one another.This is that film.

Being a tremendous 'good movie' lover, I have watched couple of thousands of Hollywood commercial as well as documentary movies till today. Leon is undoubtedly one of the best I have seen; and sure of seeing in the future to come. A superb story, excellent acting (by Jean Reno and Natalie Portman), outstanding scenic and overall direction (Luc Besson) makes the movie a treat for everyone. For all ages, whether you love action or romance/drama, this movie's a timeless Hollywood classic.I have watched this movie at least 250 times (if not more). And while watching it carefully, you can see the perfection and professionalism of all the actors/actresses involved. Every scene, each and every dialogue seems to be perfect. I tried noting down the bad scenes/bad dialogues/bad deliveries/bad angles of this movie... so far, I hardly could find any.The only couple of movies that I personally find as interesting to watch as Leon include Casablanca, Ben Hur, Gone With The Wind and Forrest Gump. Though all great movies, with superb stories and great actors/actresses; I still prefer watching Leon from time to time. As for the millions out there who still haven't watched Leon, I just have one small piece of advice: Definitely watch it. Buy a DVD, its worth each and every penny of it.

"The Professional" is a great film. The plot is simplistic, but it is touching and cuts right down to the soul. It is directed by the marvelous Luc Besson; soundtrack composed by Eric Serra. The cast is also fantastic. Jean Reno is perfect in the role as Leon, the cleaner; Natalie Portman plays the young girl who is the only one who understands him; Gary Oldman is his usual brilliant self. The film has action, heart, and soul. It is the kind of film that you can watch over and over again. I highly recommend this great film.

This is easily one of my favourite films ever made. I saw it on TV and set out to buy it the day after. Natalie Portman is the best actress you could have for that age (12 or 13. She plays the part with such talent. She has a flawless talent. The film is so beautiful the way that it shows that even a killer (scum basically) has morals. He won't let Mathilda swear, or smoke. Some people said it was sick when she says to Leon 'Can we use real bullets now?'. It's life. C'est la vie. Luc Besson has combined the story of two completley opposite parts and suceeded. I love it. All of the actors are brilliant and I believe that Natalie Portman deserves and Oscar. Get in touch if you want!!

reviews.review_title: 1994 was a good year for films.
reviews.content:
Pulp Fiction, The Shawshank Redemption, Forrest Gump, The Lion King, Quiz Show, and last, but certainly not least, Léon.Léon, AKA 'The Professional', was written in about 30 days by renowned filmmaker, Luc Besson, previously famous for his previous action-drama, La Femme Nikita. Shot in an extra 90 days, Léon is a testament to Besson's incredible talent in both directing and scripting - even if he's yet to top its brilliance.
And, yes, this movie is indeed brilliant. Every single element comes together to create an astounding crescendo of action and drama - the oscar-worthy acting by Reno and Portman, the intelligent script, the stunning cinematography, the beautiful soundtrack, the authentic effects, everything. It's just a true masterclass in film, and, to be honest, I can't imagine it would have turned out half as good if there wasn't a French director like Besson at the helm.
As Gary Oldman said, "It has the qualities of a big, hard-punching, fast-moving American movie and yet it has an injection of European cinema which I think gives it a very unique look."It'll be a while before I can get this one out of my head.
Bravo Besson!

reviews.review_title: Awesome actors, awesome plot, awesome director, awesome everything!!!
reviews.content: The Professional, is one of the best movies I have seen in a very longtime. It had me hooked from begining to the end.  To tell you the truth I didn't want it to end!  Jean Reno and Natalie Portman left me speechless!!  With such loveable characters, the plot comes to life.  It was everything I was looking for, and much more! A perfect 10!! :)

reviews.review_title: Brilliant - An Action Movie With A Heart
reviews.content: I'm not entirely sure you could call this an action movie, as it is so involving and spends a lot of time on the relationship between Leon (Jean Reno, in probably his best role yet) and Mathilda (Natalie Portman, very good in this but I haven't seen her in anything else). This relationship, teetering over the edge of romance, is fascinating enough to keep even those who are in it only for the action involved. And when there is action, it is great - The climatic fight against the SWAT team is spectacular. Also, I must mention Gary Oldman's brilliant performance. Some people call it hammy, but I love it - some people look like idiots trying to do evil people, but when he does evil, you begin to worry about wether he's really acting at all! All in all, a stylistic, involving masterpeice that's definitely one of my favourite films of all time.

i have watched the directors cut of this movie and it is one of the best movies i have ever watched in my entire life.  Natalie Portman is beautiful and wonderful acting by Jean Reno and Gary Oldman.I dont know why they had to cut 26 minutes of this film.  If you only saw the edited version, there is a whole other aspect to this movie which makes it a love story.

I love this movie.  I think it is the best performance Natalie Portman has offered us, followed by Beautiful Girls.  I Love this movie.  Jean Reno does an excellent job.  He's impnetrable and unstoppable one moment, and at teh mercy of a twelve-year old girl the next.  Fantastic. No women.  No kids.  And there you have it.  Simple ideas in an amazing film...
It's great movie for ever and I love it from beginning to end

reviews.review_title: one of the best cinematographies - congratulations
reviews.content: I would like to work like assistant such good cinematographers.

This is a great film production! Professional actors in a well mixed action/love story. When a film keeps me from the fast-forward button and only use of pause button in emergency, then you can be sure that I'll recommend others to watch and enjoy.

reviews.review_title: One of my favourite films of all time!
reviews.content: Although this film was made some time ago, I only recently purchased the movie after a recommendation from a friend whom I know is usually right about the quality of films. The first time I saw it, I liked it, after a few times i fell in love with it. I seem to get more drawn in each time! It combines an enchanting love story with the sort of action that has become a character trait for director Luc Besson. None of the three main actors (Reno,Portman,Oldman) have bettered their performances since doing this film. A special note needs to be made about the music; Eric Serra who also did the music for Le Grande Bleau and La Femme Nikita Simple has arguably created the most beautifully enchanting film score in cinematic history. A simple story, beautifully executed.

This is a story you have not seen before. It is a completely original story with a great cast. Jean Reno is a hitman who and a young Natalie Portman is a 12 year old girl. I don't know how old Portman was when she made this movie but her acting ability is undeniable even at her young age and Jean Reno shows the whole range of emotions that might come into play in these situations. I highly enjoyed this film and think most people will. Kudos to the writers. cast, and crew for showing us something new!

reviews.review_title: Good movie for the whole family.
reviews.content: The acting skills of the main characters just on top. Looks incredibly easy and at ease. I advise to view.

This is quite simply superb. The acting is great, the action is fantastic and the touches of humour are excellent. Jean Reno is one of my favourite actors, he is good in anything (he was the only good thing about Godzilla) but here he excels himself as a loner hit-man. Gary Oldman is on top form also as the deranged cop "Stansfield"One day his neighbours, who are involved with drugs are murdered, leaving their 12 year old daughter, Mathilda (a young Natalie Portman or "Princess Leia") to fend for herself. Jean Reno reluctantly takes care of her and shows her the tricks of his trade so she can kill the guy (Gary Oldman) who killed her family. The story progresses as Mathilda and Leon bond and as she plucks up enough courage to go after the men who killed her family. The end sequence is incredible as Jean Reno takes on about half of America's police to save Mathilda.10/10 Perfect

reviews.review_title: One of the best stories ever told by a criminal's perspective
reviews.content: Leon is a movie that takes us to the life of an assassin who is really professional and merciless, and expects us to look life from his eyes. It is a story about a 12 years old girl taking the revenge of her little brother who killed by cops. Mathilda, acted by a child Natalie Portman, has nowhere to go, but the assassin who saved her life by opening the door of his house to her. I really admire Besson's work and effort to create an atmosphere that led us to take side of the criminal (Leon), who is also responsible for the deaths of tens of people. Oh, yes he is a very very bad person in many ways but the director shows us how to empathy with a film character who can simply defined as BAD.Not only the directing, but also the performances have a great share of the film's success (especially Gary Oldman's). I think Natalie Portman took her first role in a film, and in the film, we have witnessed the birth of a talented actress.

Really excellent movie. Fantastic actors, and great performances by Jean Reno, Natalie Portman and Gary Oldman. The chemistry between Jean Reno and Natalie Portman was a highlight of the movie. Dialogue was minimalistic, but meaningful. The standout scene for me was when Mathilda (the character played by Natalie Portman) sought refuge from Leon (Jean Reno). At the first viewing many years ago, the scene seemed to last forever - there was that much tension to the scene. But on re-watching the movie, I noticed that the scene was actually just one minute only.
This is THE best film I've seen. It beats Titanic hands down on the emotions front, the action is brilliant and the acting is excellent (especially Natalie Portman).

reviews.review_title: One of the few movies that successfully combine all the tools available
reviews.content: Leon is one of the few movies that combine practically every basic cinematic tool, creating not only suspense and action but also atmosphere, sympathy, hate, different perspectives and a glimpse at perversity. Of course the subject 'hitman' could be used in every other 'action' movie, but Leon is more. Leon looks a bit lost, innocent almost, unable in some way to live a normal life, and not trying to because it would only interfere with his work. Matilda practically forces him to feel love and responsibility, which makes him sacrifice himself. The styling is magnificent: the movie combines baroque (Oldman) with touching minimalism (Reno). Serra's music is also remarkable, one of the first times that this aspect came to my notice as such (except of course sometimes when certain songs appeared). All this makes Leon one of my all time favorites.

This film was amazing... literally the first film to make me cry.  Natalie Portman's performance was absolutely stunning.  Jean Ruso's character and performance were the best I have seen in a VERY long time.  Gary Oldman is possibly the most terrifying character I have ever seen.  It scared me just looking at him...The storyline is amazing... With more thrills and actions sequences than Speed and True Lies combined.  It's an amazing film with an absolutely amazing cast.  If definitely worth seeing at least twice.

reviews.review_title: A film about our relationship with innocence
reviews.content: I first saw Leon a long time ago and decided to check it out again recently, which I saw the Director's Cut which is about the only director's cut of any movie which is better than the original. Leon takes place in a backward, corrupt version of New York city sometime in the modern day which is in fact the early to mid 1990s. The decade itself, coloured by Nirvana's angry Smells Like Teen Spirit and cries of protest against what had just been destroyed by the greed and gluttony of the previous era, Leon is a movie which deserves the trophy for most accurate in terms of how we approach modern urban living.Street children are often glamorised and sold back to themselves through corporate advertising campaigns, exploiting their youthful rage and earning millions from all of their troubled experiences. Rap music was coming up through the 1990s, and became popular, with a focus on the violent feud between Tupac Shakur and Biggie Smalls aka Notorious BIG.Kids were turning against the kinds of "safe" trends and towards something more dangerous towards the end of the decade, with hip hop music and grunge being the most powerful world changing genres of that decade in music. Leon is a very musical film, and as a musician, I deeply admire how it erupts and glides and moves like a piece of excellent sound.Despite the film's misunderstood perceived controversy, that of a young girl being adopted by a man whom she develops a crush on, this film is in fact a struggle between innocence and corruption.I'm not going to review this film in the way that other people will already have reviewed it, instead I am going to do what Roger Ebert did, which is to talk about how the movie made me feel, what the main themes are and my perspective on this movie culturally.The setting up of the music in the previous paragraphs gives you a suggestion that a film about a hit-man teaching a little girl how to shoot guns and take down human beings in a series of illegal murders paid for by the mob, is the kind of background upon which a rap artist might make his debut album.Grunge music may have been angry and aggressive, but it was also happy and joyous, it raged on and children raged with it, celebrated it, but were also plagued by the troubled side of the new artists. Kurt Cobain murdered himself, with a gun no less. He was arguably the most important force in rock music during the 1990s, perhaps since then.Matilda as a character is just normal, except we don't see characters like this (or didn't back then) depicted on the screen so honestly.If nothing else, this film is truthful. But rap music and grunge music, is both teenage fair, songs about killing people, about doing away with life or material possessions, about rape, murder, suicide, depression, were happening at the time of the film's release.The film came out in 1994, the year Cobain decided to shoot himself. Teenagers, particularly troubled teenagers, now had no one to follow. Matilda is one such troubled teen. She is caught between her inner knowledge of what she has felt and feels, her awakening into womanhood, and her childhood being ruined by oncoming adolescence, a bad family life and smoking.She is a typical child. So is Leon. Leon is innocent and only his job makes him have to be a bad person. He is essentially, like the other 3 main characters in the film, a contradiction; We have the obvious Gary Oldman as police officer being corrupt as a symbol of a man pretending to be a defender of justice, while being a criminal. He is bad but his job makes him seem legitimate.Leon is a good man doing very dirty work. His "guilt" is in what he does for money. He is kind and good natured in every other way. Again, this is millions of people in the corporate world who kill and have people killed, yet are wonderful family people, lovers, friends.Matilda's corruption is in what she has seen and heard, that she smokes, that she misses school on purpose, and that she wants to be a "cleaner" as well. She wants to run from what she is: a child.Leon meanwhile seems like he is trying to become innocent again. The two are in a dance between their bad selves and their good selves, we are never shown a black or white picture, just grey.The final character is Tony, a nice, kind, mobster. Again, we have a classic case of character vs role in society. Whereas Oldman's despicable police officer is cruel and evil towards other human beings, we see a hit-man and a mobster as being "good".Matilda is our own shaken sense of what we are today and what we have become emotionally. Torn between our innocent past and present day adulthood, we wish all children to be impossibly innocent yet they wish to grow up, and we wish to return to an innocence ourselves which, as the film has shown, was only ever one shade of a guilty grey.

Like i said before it`s one of my favorite movies. And i think that`s because of the very original story, a good script(written by director Luc Besson) very good acting and a very talented director.It is also a movie that is very beautiful to see,the sets and the images of the film gave me the feeling that i actually was in Little Italy in New York.But,the greatest thing in the movie is the acting. Jean Reno was brilliant as Leon,Natalie Portman(here 13 yearsold) very good and Gary Oldman was terrific.I think i like the movie so because it`s a mix of genres.Ìt`s a thriller,a drama and an actionfilm in one movie.It`s defenitely one of my favorite movies and i think it`s Luc Besson`s best movie.It`s a pitty that Leon didn`t get any awards(Oscars) because Leon deserved it.

This movie really blew me away. I expected to see a movie with an assassin who killed a lot of people and a girl who helps him with it. Never did I expect to see such a heavy-mooded emotional display of the relation growing between the old Leon, performed in all his simplicity and greatness by Jean Reno, and the 12-year-old Mathilde, performed by the superb Natalie Portman who really proves that children can act, she even outweighs Jean Reno and Gary Oldman. The plot is pretty well known I think so I won't elaborate too much but it's a plot that might not surprise you, but is sure is not the 200 million blockbuster happy ending plot you might expect. It's well laid down in the movie. (Spoiler) The dying scene of Leon is the fist actual scene in a movie where I almost couldn't hold back my tears. The relationship between Leon and Mathilde was done so well, you could almost feel his pain and her sorrow, and you felt miserably, also the way it was shot was absolutely brilliant. This scene is an instant classic. (spoiler end)all and all definitely one of the best movies ever and indeed a true addition to the top 250

reviews.review_title: Like Leon, One of the best around.
reviews.content: Leon is a great film with the right mix of action, drama and narrative. This is a compelling story of a 12-year-old girl, Mathilda and how she befriends and hires a Hit man, Leon for revenge after her family are murdered.This film from the trailers and how it is described to you might make you think this is an all out action film, you would be wrong in assuming this as most of the plot is the friendship between the girl and the Hit Man.(Spoiler Alert) The bond between Mathilda and Leon is sexual to Mathilda, however Leon sees it as a friendship between the two of them, as the story progress the Bond transforms into a Father - Daughter relationship where he has to protect and provide for her. (End spoiler).The action scene in the film are good and will satisfy the audience that have come for action, Although expect a lot of emotional scenes in between these as this is what the main narrative is focussing on. This is the best Luc Beeson film to date as he gets the characters just right. reviews.review_title: One of the Best Films Ever
reviews.content: What can one say about the masterpiece that is Leon? From it's opening that takes grabs you and never lets go, to it's final scene...It's a challenge to look away from the screen even to blink.Perhaps the greatest thing about Leon is that you don't see the actors. You look on screen and you don't see Natalie Portman, Jean Reno or Gary Oldman. Instead you really feel as if you are a fly on the wall, watching Mathilda, Leon, and Stansfield as their lives unfold around you.Not only does Reno bring alive the role of Leon, he also manages to humanize him. He takes this hit-man character, and makes you realize that there is more to him. That behind the skill, there lie the heart of a simple man who hasn't lived any other way.Portman masterfully captures the essence of the tortured soul that is Mathilda, that you really have to admire Portman for her acting chops. This could not have been an easy role for any young starlet, and yet Portman captures it perfectly. The subtle nuances, the child like innocence, and even the dark side of Mathilda's soul are portrayed excellently.But perhaps the greatest pleasure, or at least the one I enjoyed the most, was the performance of Gary Oldman. The ticks, the glazed over appearance, the dazed and confused responses, as well as the "over-the-top" craziness of Stansfield is captured beautiful through Oldman's acting. Oldman makes Stansfield so interesting, that even when he's not on screen or the focal point of a scene, you can't help but wonder what he's doing.The entire movie runs together smoothly, showing that despite his hardened ways, Leon is still an innocent soul who is just doing what he does best. And we slowly see how the innocence of Mathilda slow reaches the heart of Leon, which hasn't been reached in a very long time.Overall, an excellent movie and a recommendation for both action and drama enthusiasts.
A powerful film filled with action, drama, emotions, and music. It has great direction, a wonderful script, unforgettable performances, and a great score.

I don't understand all the hype about this movie,there are absolutely nothing special about it, the main idea of the movie was already used before! there are some really "hollywoodian" scenes that are frustrating to see how much fake it is, and not only the action scenes; I don't think that a 12 year old girl that smokes would be amazed by that piggy excuse to make the movie more sentimental. As a fan of John Woo's Hong Kong flicks I really enjoyed this part as well.Whether you're a fan of Peckinpah and Woo or you just want to watch some cool gun battles, this is a great movie, one of my new favorites.

Leon is one of the best, most original films you'll ever get the chance to see.  It is gritty, yet fast.  It is action-packed, yet startlingly artistic.  If you haven't seen it, you owe it to yourself to go rent it immediately.The cast is superb.  This was Natalie Portman's first movie, but you'll never guess it from her performance; she is stellar.  There's no description that will do her acting debut justice; you just have to see it.  Jean Reno oozes controlled danger (as he's done in so many films), but also a brilliant naivete that makes every scene enjoyable.  And Gary Oldman is one of the most disturbing bad guys you'll ever see; you start off wondering what's so scary about him, and then you see him in action and you're glad you're on the safe side of the screen.If you're wondering about the "Leon" vs. "The Professional" thing, here's the scoop as nearly as I understand it:  test screenings of the original film "Leon" were shown in the U.S., and our typically puritanical reviewers decided it contained "inappropriate content" that would put off American viewers.  So, Luc Besson and Co. had to cut out about 20 minutes of footage to satisfy our hypocritcal "powers-that-be."  The edited film was retitled "The Professional" and released stateside, while the uncut film was left "Leon" and released in the rest of the world.As a result, all you will easily find for rental/sale in the U.S. is The Professional.  Now, that's the version I saw first, and believe me, the editing job was pure artistry.  You will never miss the 20 minutes of footage if you haven't seen the full version; it's that well cut.  Go see it now, if that's all that's available to you (and it probably is).  BUT, if you can find a way to see "Leon" instead (or even afterwards), definitely do it.  For those of you who might be worried what you'd be exposed to:  there is NO nudity in either version of the film.  There is no sexual conduct or even IMPLIED sexual conduct between Leon and Mathilda.  Two kinds of things were cut out of the movie:  1.  the idea that a 12-year old girl might THINK about sex, and 2.  the idea that a 12-year old girl could learn about being a hitman.  That's it.  If the character had been 15 they would never have made them cut the movie, but hey, that's American reviewers.See it right now.  That is all.

I won't use superlatives to describe this film: but I should. Hollywood should take a lesson of what is a good plot, good actors and a good director. Besson made a masterpice in my opinion. The mix of emotions and characters is quite interesting, he has a way to develop the plot that resembles nothing I have seen. I definitely like his films.I am a fan of Jean Reno. I am a big Jean Reno fan. I was glad to see in this movie that we get a chance to see the tender side of the actor but my biggest problem with the film was his relationship with the little girl... I am still cleaning up the vomit from my floor what she decides she wants to be a hit-man too. Young orphan girl turns into hitman... give me a break, the thought is completely absurd and for me, this completely ruined the movie. When I think of the movie, I remember this part and all the other great performances are completely irrelevant. True Gary Oldman is great... a convincing psychotic.In one sense, it was a good movie for Jean Reno in that more Americans get to see him as a cold heartless killer (we like that sort of thing) a role that "appears" to come to him naturally but on the down side, we still have yet to see him in a role which he plays a "complete" quasi-normal mature human being.Perhaps the movie would have been more interesting if instead of a little girl, the relationship were with a woman... this would certainly be more palatable and then we could (at least I could ) relate to his character more.Good supporting cast i.e. Danny Aiello, Gary Oldman, great main character i.e. Jean Reno... but the fundamental premise really is absurd.

reviews.review_title: Be sure to see the "Integral version - Director´s Cut"!
reviews.content: So what to say about this movie, that I personally consider to be the best movie ever made...  ;)First, it is nice to see everytime, how great it comes out, when writer, director and cameraman are ONE person (even if Besson did not the camera in "Leon") - It shows up in so many sequences, that the writer had already in mind how a scene should be filmed as he directs the actors..Jean Reno is really brilliant, acting between a professional killer and an innocent child.But the absolute highlight of "Leon" is the first appearance of Natalie Portman. Playing 12 year old Mathilda, she gives such a wonderful performance, that I´ve seen the film now for over a dozen times - and I start to giggle immediately when Mathilda gets her "laugh-attack" in the restaurant.Of course a brilliant beast: Gary Oldman!Important note: Be sure to see the Director´s Cut (aka "Integral version") It contains more than 25 minutes that were cut out the first release. It is not just a few scenes, that might contain brutality or sex - it is just a complete part of the story.Actually, Mathilda thinks to love Leon, and wants to get closer to him, as he would let her. She is even asking him to sleep with her, which he refuses. But it seemes to be to hard for the original release of the film - (thought the marketing guys).So, anything in there: love, comedy, action, beautiful pictures and wonderful actorsStrongly recommended!

"That's not the shape of my heart..." sings Sting along the credits. But what is the shape of Leon's heart? Is he really the hard and pitiless man that he is as a hit man? The shape of his heart is the face of Matilda, a twelve year-old girl. He is primitive violence, and she, delicate innocence. He is the strength, the masculinity, the blood, and the flesh. She is the virginal uncontaminated purity. He is the child inside the man; she is the woman inside the child.Besson's masterpiece is a love story between this woman and this man, between these two children that go around NY killing people and holding each other's hands. The FBI kills Matilda's family and she decides to hire the best hit man in town to get revenge. The killer is Italian and his name is Leon. Their aim is to kill the FBI officer Gary Oldman, who assassinated Matilda's family and destroyed her life.The film is permeated with tension, a tension which is generated not only by the effective action scenes, but also by the complex relationship between Leon and Matilda. The film is about hatred, anger, revenge, violence, but also about love, humanity and justice.The performance of the actors is excellent. The director is very good at exploring the emotional intricacies of the unusual relationship between a man and a little girl. There are some sexual innuendoes, but they do not interfere with spectator's taste. Tears guaranteed.

"See, Nothing can stop love, Leon."A friend of mine asked me a very serious question the other day. It was "We already have the Professional out on DVD, Why do we need a longer version of it?" I just smiled and said "Because the world is full of precious treasures left on the cutting room floor." Ah, who am I kidding. I actually just slapped him upside the head for being such a moron. The film isn't only twenty-three minutes longer, it is twenty-three minutes better! "Leon the Professional" takes "The Professional" in a whole different direction. You still have the basic film which is one of the best action/adventure movies on the Earth and you add a doomed relationship which makes it one of the best action/dramas on the Earth.The story behind the missing twenty-three minutes is a short one. The studio which recut the film felt that the scenes involving the burgeoning relationship between Mathilda and Leon might be a tad racy for these shores. I think most people agree that they sold this audience short.True, it does discuss a taboo relationship which breaks laws, both legally and morally. But this relationship is key to the story. There never is any sight of a sexual relationship between the two, but there is the fact that Mathilda loves Leon and she wants to go the distance to prove it to him. You also have to take into account, that these are two outcasts from society. Leon is a manchild, skilled in the ways of war but not in the ways of life. Mathilda is a womanchild skilled in the ways of life, but not in war. Their situation demands that they both teach each other the tricks neccesary to survive.The missing footage also reveals some things about Leon which were unfortunate enough to be surrounded by the inappropriate scenes. This version tells more of his history. We also get to see more of his relationship with Tony (Danny Aiello.) They also reveal some of the innocence required in the dichotomy that is Leon.I know that I'm getting too deep here, but that happens with a film like this. You see it the first time and marvel at it's poignant characters and involving story. You think about it the second time and realize that you have some of the details wrong. The third time you watch it, you see that the characters are not what you felt them to be originally, and you fall in love with the movie all over again.Leon is a "cleaner" who fled to America in his younger years. He has honed his craft into being the best at his business. He runs odd jobs from time to time for Tony, who is the local head of the Italian branch of the hitmen. Tony has a good deal in Leon. He gets a skilled killer with no necessities in life. Tony doles out the money and Leon lives his simple life as he was raised. Mathilda is a young girl, spirited and headstrong. She gets thrown out of her school early in the film and Leon finds her smoking a cigarette on the steps. They share the briefest of conversations and Leon goes back to his apartment. Her father is a drug runner who has been cutting cocaine for the local hoods. His habit of cutting it too thin and making some money on the back-end ticks off those same mob men, Led by Stansfield (Gary Oldman) who coincidentally is a D.E.A. agent for the New York City police.
Stansfield comes and wipes out Mathildas family as she is running an errand for Leon. She comes home and sees the carnage and knocks on his door, praying for him to let her in. He does and she vows revenge. She also has nowhere to go and ends up staying with this quiet, gentle man. Upon learning what he does for a living, she asks him to train her. Leon agrees and the two become a team to take out the scum of the city.Mathilda however is confused about her relationship with Leon. She feels that she is falling in love with him, and he resists. Not because he knows it is wrong for a man to fall in love with such a young girl, but rather because he feels he can never love again. The two travel from apartment to apartment as they outrun the police and a rival gang. They grow closer as Mathilda finally becomes the aggressor in the relationship, and we watch as she changes from a gangly girl in love to a mature girl who knows her place in life. The relationship however, is doomed from the start as both have caused situations to grow until the point where it can only end in tragedy.The cast is superb. Jean Reno, with his droopy eyes and gangly physique becomes a man to be respected through his deeds and not his looks. His code of "No Women, No Children" is a strong motto which shows his character is although confused, still strong. Natalie Portman is well cast as Mathilda. Her innocence fades quickly and she becomes a central character in the film through her own decision skills. It was a strong part for a little girl at the time and she played it well. Gary Oldman plays Stansfield. His zoned out drug induced rages show what he is capable of. It's also interesting to see that his small part was extended into a larger one based on his skills.The disc is superbly done. Digitally remastered audio and video combined with an anamorphic presentation give this film the visual respect it deserves. Luc Besson, the director is a master at odd camera angles which enlarge the suspense. This version makes them even more enjoyable!The disc also includes: Widescreen presentation Production notes 5.1 English and 2.0 Dolby surround soundtrack Isolated music score in Dolby 2.0 channel surround International ad campaign Theatrical trailers Talent files Interactive menus English, French, Spanish and Portugese trailers 28 Chapter stopsBottom Line: A fantastic film made even better! I was going to replace my old version with this one, but instead I will add both to my collection. The reason is simple:I'll need a back-up when I wear this one out!

reviews.review_title: As moving as a myriad of melodies.
reviews.content: Until I saw "Oldboy", this was my number one favorite movie. When the introduction scene is setting, any movie goer knows immediately that there is something darkly seductive about this movie; you've only yet had a hint of the film's awe. With the sinister whisperings of dialog and script complimented by a marvelously mind-blowing movie score, the heart of the film beats vibrantly throughout one's senses. The casting calls for celebration, and the acting demands a standing ovation. Witness Gary Oldman's portrayal of a corrupted psychotic cop who's progressively descending down the psycho-pathological trail. Then there's Jean Reno's masterful delivery of Leon, a reclusive and elusive, antisocial slayer for the mob who begins his ascent from his lonely oubliette of despair. This film creates a landmark as Natalie Portman's first noticeable role, and Danny Aiello's last. Brace yourself if you've never embraced Luc Besson's triumphant masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: my idea of a romantic comedy!
reviews.content: *DO NOT READ BEFORE WATCHING THE FILM!*This is a really great movie!  When I looked at the box, I thought it was just going to be another boring action movie.  Although there is a lot of action, blowing up, killing, and guns, the real story is about love.  Off the top of my head, I can't think of a better love story in a movie.First of all, the pacing is really great.  Things are developed quickly, but not rushed.  For example, we feel pity for Matilda because we see her terrible family condition.  To me, this is a really good example of showing us, not telling us.  It is using movie-making to its full advantage.The relationship between Matilda and Leon goes at  a good pace too. Naturally, he is hesitant to accept her at first.  But because we've seen what he's seen, we can understand why he can't but not open the door to her. Their relationship is really deep.  You would think he'd be in complete control,  because he's older, he's a man, he's on his turf, but it's not that way.  Matilda is so powerful, basically because of two things.  One is sex.. well, not literally having sex, but that sexual power which controls men.  You see this when she does the impressions of Madonna and Marilyn Monroe, and also in the clothes she wears.  She always shows a lot of her body, and even though she's only 12, it's very sexy.The other power comes from vulnerability.  It sounds strange, but weakness is strength.  She knows how to appeal to Leon's instinct to protect.  Even very artificially, by putting herself in danger, by putting a gun to her own head, she can test and control Leon.In the scene where she talks to the boy on the street, you really wonder who is more powerful.  She could walk off and start a new life with someone else to take care of her, and Leon would be left feeling like crap and missing her.  But she's back with him the next scene and the relationship is actually strengthened.  Maybe she needed that, even though she didn't like the scolding at the time.The ending becomes sadder the more you think about it.  That shows great storybuilding from the beginning.  To balance out this great love story, Stan, the guy who killed Matilda's family, is really funny.  He provides comic relief, and his manner is very identifiable.  I love his lines and gestures!   I love Mozart!

reviews.review_title: Viewpoint on an American French Film
reviews.content: Luc Besson is a French Director/Producer and his American film The Professional (Leon) is an excellent example of the quality of films we could get from Hollywood if more producers were worried about quality than money.The Professional starts by showing "a day in the life" of hitman Leon (Jean Reno) as he "executes" a job given to him by his Italian contact Tony. Excellent cinematography, the violence is presented in a way that is not meant to shock.  Jean Reno, although his is French, speaks excellent English and his accent is toted as being Italian.  He portrays his character very well.   He is not an uncompassionate hired killer, but instead takes special care of his best friend, a house plant, and watches old movies at the theatre.We next meet Mathilda, a 12 year-old in an abusive home where the mother is a whore and the father is mixed up in drugs.  It is easy to understand why she is not upset when her family is gunned down by druglords, except for the loss of her 4 year-old brother.  Leon grudgingly takes her in and, after an internal struggle, decides to take care of her.This is a non-conventional love story of the emotions that grow between Mathilda and Leon and the way their love leads to what will eventually end up being the best for Mathilda.  A tragic story in the traditional French vein.

reviews.review_title: As good as it gets in the genre!

More family than romance with the relationship that develops between a young girl and a seasoned Assassin.  Unfortunately the violence and swearing does attract an R Rating in Australia.A must for humanists who believe that Assassins can have feelings and who feel for the loneliness this profession would create.  Gary Oldman plays a role we are familiar seeing him in: a psychotic killer (actually an undercover cop)- hey he does it well!  Jean Reno (Leon) is both lovable and lethal; most of all convincing as the Assassin with honour and standards. Natalie Portman as the 12 year old Mathilda is cute, loveable and delightfully naughty:  I think we'll be seeing more of her in the future- very talented.  The rest of the cast are mostly type-cast but it all melds well to make this a well rounded albeit hard to box motion picture.  If you like a good bit of action and the skill of a talented Assassin coupled with a sweet story of an unusual relationship don't miss this one!

Leon isn't exactly an out an out action thriller. It's cleverer than that. I'd describe it as an action drama, because apart from the setpiece finale, there's very little action. When Mathilda's (a stunningly good Natalie Portman) family are wiped out by corrupt DEA agent Stansfield (Gary Oldman is undoubtedly the nastiest of all his screen villains) she is taken in by hitman loner Leon (Jean Reno), and taught how to "clean" (kill people), while she gives him a taste for life. Most of this film is about Leon and his growing love for Mathilda, and so there is not that much action. However, Director Luc Besson pulls out all the stops for the blistering twenty minute siege on Leon's apartment, when an army of cops and SWAT teams go up against the hitman. The scene leaves you literally breathless, and you really want Leon to win, and blow Stansfield away. That would happen if this were a standard Hollywood actioner, but it's not, it's directed by Luc Besson, for God's sake and the ending, however miserable, is a breath of fresh air.

I saw "The Professional" for the first time recently, and the experience was indescribable.  All of the elements of this film mesh together so exquisitely: directing, writing, cinematography, and acting."The Professional" is a slick pseudo-action film about Matilda (Natalie Portman), a 12-year-old girl whose family is gunned down by double-crossed DEA agent (Gary Oldman), over a drug dispute.  Matilda happened to be out buying groceries at the moment, and comes home before the thugs leave. She sees that her family is dead, but walks past, pretending not to notice. Instead, she knocks on a neighbor's door in search of sanctuary.  The neighbor, Leon, (Jean Reno) reluctantly lets her in.  She soon finds out that Leon is in fact a hitman.  She convinces him that he is now responsible for her life since he saved it, and she asks him to teach her to be a "cleaner" like him so she can avenge her brother's death.  Leon eventually agrees, and Matilda ends up teaching the reclusive Leon a few things about living.All of the acting was superlative, especially Portman in the role of the streetwise Matilda.  One thing I really liked about the movie that I think most people misunderstand is the relationship between Leon and Matilda. The way I saw it, they both loved each other, but Leon's love was a father's love for his daughter.One last note: I have heard about the director's cut, but in my opinion it is not as good as the edited version.  The director's cut (according to what I heard) extremely overplays Matilda's seduction of Leon, a subject that wasn't even covered in the edited version.  This results in a loss of the ambiguity of their relationship, which is what I really liked about it.In short, that was why the movie worked so well: it was just ambiguous enough that it kept you guessing, even after you have finished watching it. This movie makes you think.

reviews.review_title: You have no comprehension of Besson's work.
reviews.content: While I will agree that Natalie Portman and Reno aren't at the top of their game, I have a few serious problems with your review.1) Luc Besson's entire career is based on redoing and making fun of older movies. Subway is a mockery of Trufaut, Fifth Element is a pastiche of every hokey Sci-Fi melodrama out there, The Messenger is a parody of Braveheart and The Big Blue is the nature film mixed in with the sports contest film. Leon is no different. To claim that Besson is nothing more than a French director trying to make a buck by recreating an American film is to say that Quentin Tarantino is no better, as his acclaimed Resevoir Dogs is nothing more than a remake (oh, sorry, outright plagiarism) of City on Fire.2) Leon is NOT Besson's first film. As far as I know, Subway was, which (wow!) starred Christopher Lambert. Get your facts straight and do some background before you put the poison pen down.

reviews.review_title: a modern myth of salvation and redemption

The action scenes are thrilling and very well done; more importantly, they are woven into a comprehensive tale of high moral value. In the end, the love between the maiden and the prince is pure and sacrificial.The relation to the movie Ghost Dog; the way of the samurai is interesting. The latter movie is also one of salvation and redemption, somewhat more overtly spiritual but aimed in the same direction. They make a great set.

Is. For example, the film's opening action, in which Leon must frighten the fat criminal, is dedicated to paying Leon as a professional and ruthless assassin. reviews.review_title: action-drama-romance, and the best of all three!
reviews.content: In short, go see Leon.I will not tell you anything about this movie, except that it is a true art piece.  However, if you see The Professional, you might be disappointed. reviews.review_title: I love to hate Gary Oldman...and you hate him in this movie.
reviews.content: Please watch this movie! The good guy is the bad guy, and the bad guy is the good guy. I think the relationship between Leon (Reno) and Mathilda (Natalie Portman) makes most people feel awkward, but I think that is what Luc Besson wanted.It's got action. Romance (sort of). A credible plot (if not a bit surreal). Excellent photography. REAL Suspense. And, most importantly, it's a very original movie with truly excellent acting from the three main characters.

reviews.content:
Many films we go back and watch tend to leave us with some level of disappointment. Leon is one of the most emotionally intense movies ever made. French director Luc Besson uses everything: actors, music, camera angles, lighting to create an unique experience - "It's not realism, it's not naturalism - it's heightened reality" as Gary Oldman very well put it.In "The making of The Professional" Besson says "If I imagine somebody in the street try to knock on my daughter, I kill the guy, in five seconds. I kill him, and I think "It's in me, I'm a beast!" On this part we can't forget that a part of us, the genetic things inside are much, much older than The Ten Commandments". He certainly uses visceral scenes to create very strong emotion in the movie - the blood running from Mathilda's nose or Stansfield's unforgettable "EVERYONE!" are just a couple of examples. The music and the sound are excellent and are used in a masterly fashion - you can hear Fatman's heart beating desperately or a low claustrophobic sound when Stansfield turns to look at Mathilda's father.However Leon does not work only on this primary level, it also has an intelligent story. It may seem to be almost a fairy-tale, but don't be fooled - just like his character Besson is serious. This movie has a message: without love we are dead, even if we don't see it. Only true love give meaning to our lives: "everything else reminds me a big yogurt: warm and rancid" as Mathilda says in the original script, which is available on the net under the name Leon Version 1. Is this true in "real life"? I don't know but this movie can make you wonder.Then of course there's the sensuality. It's hypocritical to deny it, the camera interacts with Mathilda in a mesmerising fashion. It's not sick and it's not degrading: it's art, subtle and beautiful.Leon is not perfect but it has so many great moments that all its flaws can be forgiven. It's a movie that really should not be missed, unless you are concerned with its amorality. And don't be - Leon is less violent than many action movies and the unusual relationship between the main characters is handled mostly with genuine feeling and tact.

Where to start? for me this movie fits in the rare class of movies that i randomly snatched from the Blockbuster shelves to kill an evening, only to be subsequently floored by it (Fight Club being the other major example). it's a beautiful film, bookended by two of the most amazing action sequences i have ever had the joy to behold. the performances are near flawless, the cinematography is amazing, and it flows wonderfully.Jean Reno's man-child portrayal of Leon is amazing. watching him go from a calm, cool killer from the shadows to the confused wonder of taking care of Mathilda is a joy to watch.Then there's Stansfield.I have always loved psychos on film, and Stansfield is one of the greatest. Gary's wired, drugged-out, sociopath DEA agent is a spectacle. the top down shots of him cracking the pills, not to mention the infamous "EVERYONE!!!" are forever etched on my memory.then there's Mathilda. for Portman to convey the sheer weight of that role, at her age, is nothing short of a minor miracle. she's... words don't so it justice. you just have to see it.so you may be wondering, "if you liked the movie THAT much, why didn't you give it a ten instead of a nine?" and it would be a fair question, which i will now answer.because i am now completely incapable of finding Natalie Portman attractive.every time i see her in an attractive outfit, i see innocent little 12-year-old Mathilda, dressed a little too provocatively for comfort, and my mind grinds to a halt. i know it's petty, but this movie has ruined the beauty that is Portman for me forever.

Jean Reno is great as the professional killer Leon, who lives a ordinary if not lonely life, divided between his job(murdering or so to say "telling" them to do the right thing) and the old black-and white movies. Natalie Portman makes a wonderful performance of the little Matilda. But the really terrific actor is Gary Oldman. His character Stansfield is the key one- thanks to him we can realize the other face of the police force, and he is the main reason we can see what Leon is capable of. I liked Leon, And hope you will.

reviews.review_title: Starts off Excellent, Goes Downhill From There
reviews.content:
Superb opening sequence. Leon really does come across as a professional, yet possesses a somewhat childish demeanour with other aspects of his life, and follows a strict regular regimen.The beginning of his acquaintance with Mathilda is emotionally up lifting: seeing him trying to help the bereaved Mathilda get back up on her feet was great.Natalie Portman's acting is superb.I also liked the cinematography, especially during the opening sequence.The cons:
The sexual tension between the 2 of them (or at least from Mathilda alone) is uncomfortable to say the least. Others may claim that Leon never did reciprocate, but there are 2 points to this: her actions alone are provocative enough; for instance claiming to the receptionist that they are "lovers". Leon also tells her he loves her and wants to spend the rest of his life with her in the end. Not to mention the constant showcasing of her bottom, scantily dressed clothing, etc. This may be "normal" to some people, but it shouldn't be.The thesis of the movie is supposedly centered around training Mathilda into a "cleaner" who is as good as Leon. Sure Leon does attempt to train Mathilda, and I can appreciate the time/scenes spent on depicting said training. But what was the training ever used for? Nothing! We never get to see Mathilda using her skills. The only thing she ever did was fire fake bullets and stick some gum on the peekholes of their targets. Massive letdown.What was the point of showing Leon being siphoned out of his earnings (or perhaps I was mistaken and his boss was honestly safeguarding it for him), Leon wanting to pass it on to Mathilda if he were to die, and then seeing Mathilda ending up in the restaurant with his boss offering to give her a hundred bucks a month? It does not add any sentimental, emotional, or purpose to the movie, apart from giving us the scene where Leon tells Mathilda that he has a bunch of money stored before letting her slide down the shaft.Underwhelming movie overall. Loved the first ~50 minutes though.

reviews.review_title: Leon: The Professional is one of the best movies of the 1990s
reviews.content: Leon: The Professional is one of the best movies of the 1990s. If you have seen it, you probably agree. If you haven't, you should. It's a mobster movie crossed with a coming-of-age story, but it is more than the sum of those parts.Leon: The Professional has been criticized for being violent and overly cynical. But those qualities are part of what makes it great. Movies that do not take violence seriously are worse than shallow-they are dishonest. And a movie that does not take human nature seriously is worse than shallow-it is meaningless.Leon: The Professional does not have an overt message about human nature, but its characters and situations speak volumes. And what they say is worth listening to, because there is something there for everyone.

I am buying a DVD player next month so I can see the version integrale with the deleted scenes and without world's worst pan-n-scan.The movie's treatment of the Mathilda character is difficult for some. Her relationship with Léon is, of course, the beautiful, painful, redemptive heart of the film.  How odd, that we're used to seeing pubescent girls kill in movies, but seeing one experience an intense attachment is disturbing to us.

Jean Reno plays Leon, a hitman. Coldly efficient, cunning and extremely deadly. The movie begins with Leon performing a hit, killing without remorse and then going home. Leon leads a simple life, although he gets $5000/head, he leaves this money in the trust of his friend and employer Tony(Danny Aiello). He seems to live on two quarts of milk a day, sleeps sitting up, stays in a small flat, and exercises rigorously. His only companion is his plant, which he cares for meticulously. He has fallen into a comfortable routine and is at peace with himself.That all changes one day, when crooked DEA agents led by the supremely evil Stansfield(Gary Oldman in a waaay over the top performance) storm his next door neighbor's apartment in search of drugs. They slaughter everyone who lives there, save the tiny, 12 year old Mathilda(Natalie Portman in a heart rending performance). She slips by the DEA agents and goes to Leon for help. Against his better judgement, Leon takes her in  and this is where the real movie begins. The relationship between the cold, remorseless killer and the little girl who has aged beyond her years. Leon teaches her the "Cleaning" business and Mathilda shows Leon how to live again. Early in the film Mathilda asks Leon "Is life always this hard, or is it just when you're a kid?" and Leon coldly replies, "Always like this." We get the sense that Leon knows what he is talking about, that his life has taken so many wrong turns, that now he cares for nothing.Jean Reno is a revelation. I had previously only seen him in Ronin, and while I thought he was acceptable in that movie, his performance here goes leagues beyond what he did in that film. His Leon is portrayed as a calm, ruthless but also nervous and emotionally insecure assassin. In Natalie Portman, I am reminded of a very young Milla Jovovich, but perhaps that is because of foreknowledge of director Luc Bessons fondness for Ms. Jovovich. Natalie Portman gives an assured performance that is remarkable for one so young. Everything else I've seen her in, it appears her talents are wasted. (It is actually making me look forward to the next Star Wars movie). Gary Oldman's characterisation of Stansfield is so out of this world that it seems very out of place in this picture. Danny Aiello gives strong, stable support(as always).This is Luc Besson's strongest work out of the ones that I have seen (Fifth Element and the Messenger). I think his use of color, his compositions and stylization are great, but that sometimes he does not take the time or takes to get the elements and the performance just right. Hopefully he will continue to mature as a director.But these are minor quibbles and do not affect the overall impact of the film. I highly recommend this movie.****/*****

reviews.review_title: A richly acted, subtle film that draws on the three main actors.
reviews.content: Luc Besson's Leon is a very well constructed piece. The film's three main actors all deliver excellent performances, although it is the intense acting of Natalie Portman that makes the film shine. The relationship between her and Leon (Jean Reno) is developed at a fast pace, broken only by the cracks which begin to show - widened by Stansfield's relentless and drug-crazed pursuit. A stunning film for many different reasons.

Apart from the excellence in acting, directing, editing and camera-work that can be seen/experienced in this movie, I love the way it is structured like a classic phantasy-epic: the protagonists who supplement each other, where one is as important as the other; the evil 'overlord' surrounded by his minions; the wise old man figure (Aiello); the shakespearian- like tragedy; the final, almost carthatic clash. It is this 'mystic' feeling that makes this movie so special to me.

And the ending is what makes the movie brilliant. Thats why i like the movie that much. You know what I mean after you've seen the movie.SOO GO AND RENT IT NOW!!!!!

OK. I was thinking a long time, before writing this comments. Like almost everyone out there I liked this movie for it story, cast etc. I could go on and on about the great performances of the actors, great directing job, how it's a story of a "bad guy" doing a good thing, or a "good guy" doing a bad thing, etc.I am not going to sit here and preach about how little Mathilda was Exploited sexually, I am not going to be sitting here wondering about what happened to the families of the swat team members killed by Leon, and for sure I am not going to be wondering if DEA officer Stansfield went to hell. People, some of us are taking things too seriously, and at the same time we are taking things for what they are not. Just because little Mathilda had a crush on Leon doesn't mean that this is a pre-teen porn flick. Just because some people got killed, doesn't mean that you are watching evening news, with real guns.What we got here is a great story by Mr. Luc Besson. Story that he showed us Using such great actors as Natalie Portman, Jean Reno, Garry Oldman and Danny Aiello. And what is frustrating me is the fact that people, who value movies for what they are: Entertainment; are striped of the chance to see the whole story, as intended by storyteller - the director; just because somebody who was lucky enough to see the full version decided that this movie is something it is not. And for sure the one thing this movie is not is a disturbing picture.So now I am going to leave you here, for all of you got some thinking to do.And me? I am going to be a cleaner move to Hollywood, and clean some decision-making executives.

reviews.review_title: excellent! The "international version" is the best!
reviews.content: I saw the original release of "The Professional" here in the US, I loved the movie then.  I recently saw the "international version" that added 24 minutes back into the movie and it made the movie 10x better!While some of the dialog and subject matter in the scenes that were added back in might be of the squimish and somewhat uncomfortable type, it's well worth having it in the movie.  It's talked about in other genre's like song (e.g. "Don't Stand So Close To Me" by The Police), why not the movies.It also needs to be in there b/c you learn so much more of the character of Leon.  In the US version, you would think he got into trouble b/c of a woman (like she screwed him over financially), but in this version you find out that that is as far from the truth as you can get.An excellent movie.  I'm really quite annoyed with the MPAA if they prohibited this version from theatrical release or caused a "chilling" affect to make the director or distributors of this film not want to release it here in the States.

I would like to point something which the critics of this film missed, they often say that Natalie Portman was 'abused', and that Mathilda was almost pornographic in the film.In Léon, Luc Besson reverses the ages of the two main characters, Léon himself is made to seem childish, always drinking milk, and not being able to read, whereas Mathilda is streetwise and cynical, she is made to seem much older than her years. In this way, Mathilda is quite old enough for the love content of the film.This aside, Léon is a brilliant film, well worth watching.(10/10)
