This has to be Besson's most brilliant film to date; it is beautiful, poetic and stylish in equal measures. Natalie Portman is terrific, showing acting ability beyond her 14 years in the film, and Reno displays his effortless charm and aptitude in playing a tragic character. Besson achieves something great in making the story amazing to watch, using emotive camera angles and imagery, coupled with Eric Serra's heart-stopping soundtrack to excellent effect.

reviews.review_title: Why I keep on watching this excellent piece of cinema
reviews.content: Since I've watched this movie I'll never been the same. Great opening scene, nice tempo, shy Jean Reno, unforgettable Gary Oldman and breath-taking guitar and voice of Sting at the end... Serra's more eastern-like score matches strangely good with the Big Apple-atmosphere. Watch how Stansfield opens the curtain at Mathilda's home, and get chilled by the grace of it. "You don't like Beethoven!" No, I prefer this movie.

The American release called The Professional has about 23 minutes cut out, so go and find the "Integral" version or the director's cut.  Because if you watch the director's cut after the cut version, then it's like watching a different movie.  Things that take place make much more of an impact in the director's cut.  Now, the American release is still great but, the Leon version is incredible.  No other hitman movie can top it!!  I guarantee it!

reviews.review_title: Another typical movie form Luc Besson.....
reviews.content: Luc Besson. He is the man that can be trusted with directing fine movies with artistic flair. Leon is a fine example of Besson at his best: misunderstood? maybe... Difficult? almost certainly....Satisfying? Definitely.Jean Reno is quite superb in the title role. Like his character, he shuns any limelight, favoring a simple existence. With his performance, Reno commands respect: the viewer will feel like he/she is on autopilot for most of this movie. The viewer will allow Jean Reno to put in the best performance of his career, will allow Natalie Portman to portray a very convincing 12 year old, will allow Gary Oldman to be his usual excellent self. To say much more would give away the plot of this most enjoyable movie. Actually it wouldn't, but what the hell? Leon is a great movie. The plot is simple: gangsters get something wrong, and revenge must be extracted.  Well done Monsieur Besson, Monsieur Reno et Madmoiselle Portman. The rating has to be  9/10

reviews.review_title: An action and drama rolled into one
reviews.content: after being very impressed by Luc Bessons french film Nikita there was no way I couldn't watch this film, so I did. Amazimgly this film was slightly better than Nikita. The plot is an Italian hit-man Leon lets an abused young girl into his Apartment as she has no where else to go, Leons life becomes very different after her arrival.The movie perfectly blends larger than life action and very emotional drama together. The movie is helped largely by some great acting performances by all the characters in particular Gary Oldman (who seems to have no end to the roles he can play)as a slightly crazy crooked cop, Natalie Portman and Jean Reno work together brilliantly some of the scenes were Portman says very awkward things are pretty hard to watch as they are so realistic you can imagine yourself in Reno's position, he doesn't really know how to reply but the acting he does with his facial expressions alone are brilliant and tell the story.I honestly think this gem stands proudly alongside such films as scarface and pulp fiction (your probably laughing right now) this film would have been fairly ordinary had it not been for the dark humour present.I have heard that the longer version of this film builds the characters a lot more and is better. I have only seen the version which apparently has around 20 minutes or more cut out I am going to try my hardest to find the other version it truly would be a masterpiece if it's better than this.
This film changed my feelings of life But the end is bad Unfortunately
Reno and Portman have palpable chemistry in this beautifully directed action drama, and Oldman is one of the best villains ever!

I just saw LEON, the international version on DVD, and i must say that the story and the characters were so real and human, which i found to be a wonderful element for an action film, this is what makes a film so enjoyable, all the elements come together , violence, action, mixed in with real people whom we care about and watch them bond, thus feeling and emotion play a part, and we feel like we are experiencing the drama unfold right in our own lives.  Gary Oldman is awesome as usual, and Natalie Portman is superb! See this movie and you will love it!

reviews.review_title: one of the best movies I've ever seen
reviews.content: Everything about this movie was amazing, I'm so glad I finally watched it after putting it off for so long

reviews.review_title: The greatest action movie of all time
reviews.content: This is my favorite film of all time. Despite this film being an action classic, the action takes a backseat during most of the film for it to build the characters and relationship of Mathilda and Leon. You will feel uncomfortable at times, but you will still feel for these characters just as much. This film is an experience, it isn't a large scope like the modern day blockbusters. It is a film that is not slow, but takes time for it to develop its characters so in the end your heart is wrenched when Leon dies. Truly one of the most impactful character deaths in film I have ever seen. Then to see Mathilda, completely alone with no one in her life, go and plant his favorite plant into the ground to give it roots breaks my heart every time. This performances are phenomenal--Gary Oldman destroys this rule and is truly terrifying and off-putting. Jean Reno brings this amazing child-like and equally serious feel to the character of Leon that should be more widely recognized. Natalie Portman is amazing in this film and gave one of the greatest child performances of all time. I would recommend this film to anyone.

reviews.review_title: leon-the best 9 out of ten film ever made
reviews.content: What can you say a near perfect film,after the first 2 minute action sequence which can only be described as 80's cheesy action(and by the way the only reason it didn't get 10 out of 10)you get a great story of love and revenge told through the eyes of a 14 year old girl-played by natalie portman who is on career best form,why didn't she get Oscar nomination? You've got to watch this film,everyone i know whose watched it loves it.The story starts with portman being made an orphan and homeless after her family are shot dead,so she turns to the only person she knows leon an assassin who cant read or write.She offers to teach him in return he teaches her how to kill to get revenge for her family.There's an under current in the film in which the two leads fall in love there's even a hint they've had sex,i know what your thinking a 14 year old girl and a grown man but its tastefully done.This film will tug at your heart strings
This is one of my favourite films and Natalie Portman is one of my favourite Actresses. Not really finding out that she played this role until a later date. Story Cinematography was great!

This movie is very profound. There is not a lot to say about this movie beside that its filled a void in cinema from beginning to end. Absolutely deep and sensuous romance and thriller. Acting and story were good, but who cares. Just enjoy the relationship and fist in the face of convention.

Great movie......Funny, tragic, brilliant,amazing and unmissable.Gary Oldman is perfect... Leon is quite possibly the finest work by director Luc Besson, whom is for me anyways, a director who is hit and miss. The Professional is a stunning piece of cinema that is near perfect, and displays an exhilarating, well paced plot that boasts impressive performances all around. I can watch this a million times....even back-to-back. This film was absolutely amazing. I have spent hours re-watching various scenes and noticing all the perfection with which they are acted and directed. It's not the violence or action sequences that make this movie so great, but rather moments like where Mathilda knocks on Leon's door. It would be so easy to just film the door opening, but instead we see light illuminating Natalie Portman's face, symbolizing something angelic. And the moment has so much more meaning.

reviews.review_title: One of my favotire action film
reviews.content: Usually action film do not have a good story line, this is one of the few films that have strong story, strong character and great action.

One of the many great aspects of Leon is the performance of Jean Reno who really shines in the role of a hitman. But I think, whats makes his performance greater is the fact that he is confronted with one of the best actress in hollywood right now..Natalie Portman. Never in all my life an actress had me make laugh and cry as easily as miss Portman. Leon being her first movie, I think no other actresses could have been that good.The movie is also a good thrill-ride with no dead moments. Action scenes are great and the psychology of the characters is well integrated to the plot. The only bad thing of this movie to my taste is the performance of Gary Oldman who is, as always way, over the top. But I think its the whole characters that sucks.. too unbelievable.Besson did a great job on this movie. I think in fact that this movie was his last good movie.
A masterpiece that everyone should watch and learn from.
One word watch it. Because it's dram is one of the bests.

Leon (The professional) is well worth a watch anyone, whether you are an action fan or not.Leon is a hit-man at the top of his game, always completes his mission and never gets hurt, never gets caught. He charges $5,000 dollars a head, no women and no children, those are the rules. However he lives alone with little possessions, his only friend is a plant and he sleeps in a chair, next to his bed. However his life changes suddenly when his neighbour's ( a 12 year old Natalie Portman) whole family are killed by a bent cop and his team. She survives however, and runs to leon for help. He takes her in and teachers her how to become a hit-man to get revenge on the murderers. Yet a strange relationship of friendship and love unfolds between them and leon ends up having to rescue her once again as the bent cops find out her whereabouts.The film has little flaws and is a jolly good watch! The acting is superb, portman gives a fine performance of a child who's family has just been killed. Reno has little to say but is perfectly cast in the role has leon. However, the fine talents of Gary Oldman steal the show as a superb bent cop. With lines such as 'I like these clam little moments before th storm', where can you go wrong. This is easily his best performance ever and really terrifies the ordinance. The only flaw is the whole concept of leon teaching a 12 year old girl how to become a hit-man? Bit stupid really as she never kills anyone. BUt overall it is a masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: Rapidly rising to the top of my favourite films ever - SPOILERS INNCLUDED!
reviews.content: The interplay of the main characters is the thrust of this film - Leon, an 'innocent'adult, and Mathilda, a street-wise child, and Norman, virtually the embodiment of evil. I think this is possibly Gary Oldman's best role. His ability to give the audience a summary of his character's approach to life, purely by the look on his face in his opening scene is the talent of a great film actor. Some critics have accused Oldman of over-acting, but I think he portrays his character as 'larger than life' because his character really believes he is invincible, and can do precisely as he pleases. When he shoots at the old lady to reinforce the instruction to return to her apartment, he hits the window. It wasn't a warning shot, it was simply a luck coincidence for her that he was too stoned to aim straight! Leon's initial dismissal of Marthilda's plight is entirely in keeping with his character, and his gradual 'adoption' of her shows the emotional side previously restricted to the tender care of his pot plant - a metaphor throughout the film for the two of them, who want only someone, or even something, to love. The final optimism that Mathilda will survive is encapsulated in her planting of Leon's plant, and with it his memory. Maybe Shakespere got it wrong, perhaps the good that men do lives after them, and the evil is interred with their bones, at least that's true for Leon.

Just an everyday tale of three Psycopaths,one of them twelve years old. Gary Oldman is doing a good job of ridding the world of drug dealers and their horrible families when the applecart is upset by a deranged serial killer and his young apprentice.Its a bit of a tragedy cos our hero Gary gets killed but at least he takes that nasty Leon with him.The girl grows up to become La Femme Nikita, or worse, Natalie Portman. Acting honours go to the plant.I give it 10 stars because I think hit men ( hit people ? ) are really cool and as this film shows,really just a misunderstood section of the population with hearts of gold.Perhaps there's a little hit-man in all of us.Whadya think ?I have to go now because the needle on my moral compass is spinning like a Tasmanian Devil with a fire cracker up its backside.I will just finish by reminding you all of the important things in life :1. Don't kill women and kids.2. Try not to spill your milk.3. Make friends with a plant.4. If a twelve year old girl comes on to you,try and keep an open mind.Just follow these few simple rules and you wont go far wrong in life.

This movie was entertaining right off the bat. I'm a fan of the movie Lolita and tons of action/crime movies as well and this made the perfect combination. It's cute, funny, dramatic and action packed all in one. I had actually been listening to the song Matilda by Alt J for years and had no idea what the song was about until I read through the comments on YouTube. After watching the movie, the song gave me chills.I'm amazed I haven't seen it yet, I typically lean towards the 90's action and humor.

Unwillingness to lead a righteous life can be condemned without reference to any country or era. At the same time, the inability to live an ordinary life needs, most likely, sympathy. Life is strikingly different from existence. In the first case, even a dishonest person can proudly say that in this world someone else needs and is sincerely attached to something. In the second case, the subject has only the notorious "groundhog day", no goal and motivation, but only a continuous swim without a rudder and sails. You can only be happy for self-sufficient individuals who are as comfortable as possible alone with themselves. All other people necessarily need the affectionate eyes of a person who has become a native and words that do not need to be deciphered: "you will never be alone."Even to himself he could hardly admit his unhappiness. He was used to suppressing even the sprouts of feelings. A professional whose services will always be in demand. A performer who is used to not asking unnecessary questions. A killer whose unwritten code of honor will be executed even on the verge of death. He lost one house, never finding another in return. His name is Leon. He has been growing a beard for a long time, but at heart he is a boy who has not learned to dream. Instead of the hot drinks so familiar to people of his circle, he prefers milk, whose white color seems to purify the soul from the methodically violated commandments of God. What is life in Leonov's understanding? A potted plant that will reach for the sun all its short life. The killer himself hides his eyes from the luminary behind dark glasses. Because Leon didn't have a person to whom he could entrust his kind, sad look. Not yet...Unlike the laconic "cleaner", the neighbor's girl can tell anyone who is not indifferent about the vicissitudes of fate. A family that doesn't really exist. Childhood, where there is no joy of growing up. There is only one source of light in a life woven of impenetrable darkness - a little brother. Millstones alien to children's understanding of adult realities grind this tiny spring. The girl's name is Matilda. She's still very young, and they just can't take her seriously. She desperately wants to grow up as soon as possible to bring justice to her brother's murderers. But at the same time, she still does not cease to be a child, violently clutching a stuffed rabbit in her hands. Physically unable to put her thoughts and aspirations in order, she can meanwhile see kindness in the huge eyes of a shy killer. Because Matilda did not have a person who could believe her and recognize her as "his". Now he has appeared...

French director Luc Besson in 1994 made the film Leon with Jean Renaud in the title role. This is one of his best roles. Here he plays a killer, tenderly caring for a ficus. Someone has a cat, someone has a dog, and Leona ficus is an object of universal love. It's a pleasure to watch it. Soon Matilda appears in his life - a little girl, Leon's neighbor, whose family was brutally murdered. Matilda, played beautifully by Natalie Portman, asks Leon to teach her craft in order to avenge this death. Natalie has become so accustomed to the role of Matilda that it seems that we are not looking at a young actress who has played only one role before, but an experienced actress who has played quite a lot of roles. I am also surprised by the role of Gary Oldman, who played a corrupt policeman. It was he who killed Matilda's family in cold blood. He is a great actor, and in Leon Gary was on top. I've watched this movie a lot of times, and with each new time it looks like the first time. And this is thanks to Luc Besson.

If you haven't seen this movie go and rent it right now!!! I prefer the Director's cut version, it's better than the original!!! One bad thing is that, Luc Besson is planning a sequel and I think that will ruin the whole story.

I think this film was execellent. Not only was the story perfect and ORIGINAL (which most films today aren't)but the characters were complex and cool at the same time. Luc Bessons finest. It starts off with Leon on a hit mission. Then as the story progresses you begin to see the friendship grow between Leon and Matilda. But as he teaches her the trade, Cop Stansfield begins to get suspicios. But the final shootout was what really makes this film a classic. Excellent scripting ideas and intricate camera work make it a masterpeace! But in the end you are left with a sense of happiness and sadness. Don't worry you'lle understand what I mean once you see it.

having watched this movie 20 times, i still tend to switch off the tv afterwards and reflect on this unique movie. if movies are to show emotions then this is one of the very best there is. portman/reno give a fabulous performance always balancing between father+daughter relationship and lolita aspects. in strong contrast to this are the excellent action sequences and the tragic storyline links both very well.really a movie to watch and enjoy!

This is without doubt a classic film in its original state. It is a touching story of an unique relationship. In the American version it is obvious that the audience haven't been deemed to have the stomach for anything like an un-PC subject.I find this strange, because although there is obviously a strong love between the two lead characters, there is nothing sleazy, or at anytime worrying about Leon's intentions towards Mathilda. I am sure that most young girls get a crush on an older man at some point, whether it be a teacher or whoever, and the fact that Leon takes Mathilda in and looks after her in his own simple way, gives her a sense that she is wanted in a way she never got from her family.Leon is a visual treat, Besson almost at his best. The story is told without rush, and has many hidden depths. Most of these are looked at further in the director's cut. All the roles are well played, although Oldman has a bad habit of over-acting, but still gets away with it.This film marks an end to Besson's golden era and the start of his Americanization and selling out in films like The Fifth Element, though still a good film.Leon is a must see film... 9.5/10

The Professional is one of those rare gems, that looks and acts like an action film, but is hiding a love story within. The ability of this movie to excite, enthrall and move you is virtually unheard of in the action genre, and the acting (Reno, Portman and Oldman are incredible), direction, pacing and script are excellent.I can't say enough good things about this beautiful movie, and unlike some of the US blockbusters that are easily forgotten, The Professional will stay with you for some time.

reviews.review_title: One of my ten favorites of all time...
reviews.content: It is rare when a director takes as much time to set moods as was taken with this phenomenal film. For one example, in a brief shower scene, our "Cleaner", Leon, without a single word, tells us of his terrible torment between what he does, and what he wishes he was not compelled to do. So much tension, so little time... I am not a member of the film-making community, and I don't have the "professional" verbiage to communicate my impression of this film, but if you LIVE for the unbearable (what I prefer to call) "stretch-to-snap", this is your film. The violence of wanton, mindless, remorseless murder contrasted with unbearable tenderness, compassion and empathy, all rolled into one roller-coaster ride of a film. There are a few moments when credulity must be suspended, i.e., just how DID Leon get into that SWAT uniform so bloody fast--, but WHO CARES?--the bulk of the film more than makes up for it. A must see for sure. Also, Gary Oldham at his absolute FINEST. So evil, you just want to punch his lights out!

reviews.review_title: The best "love" story I've ever seen!
reviews.content: Although it might not seem like a really interesting film since the idea looks rather unoriginal, the usual guy who meets the girl and this changes his life, Leon has characteristics which few films have. Even though you might not think it during the film, you are actually siding with one of the bad guys, since Leon isn't exactly an angel! But this makes the story even more spicy. What is also a bit strange about the story is the fact that the so called "love" story occurs between an adult man and a twelve year old girl. It is ironic that at the end, the pro ends up dying and Mathilda's life returns to how it would have been if nothing had ever happened, as in going to the school for troubled girls. Ultimately Leon lives on in his plant his "best friend, just like [him]". This is certainly one of the best films I've ever watched, and it certainly one worth watching for those who haven't watched it already!

Generally the movie is very good(it could be better if some sci-fi action killings by Leon were minimized).However,Gary Oldman who stars as the corrupted DEA officer Norman Stansfield really rocks!.He really is a very versatile actor and it is not possible to think of someone else who could perform like this.He deserved an Oscar,that is for sure.Watch it,just for the vicious Stansfield and i am sure you will agree that he really is... at your service!!

This movie has it all and should keep all watchers no matter their preference entertained for the full duration.In my mind, this movie works so well because of the exploration of the relationship between Leon and Matilda, the fact that Leon is a very cool hitman really becomes inconsequential after the first 20 minutes or so of play time. This is one of the few movies I will happily sit and watch the credits roll as the perfect choice of Sting for a closing song gives you perfect time to soak it all in.If you want to see this movie at its best, get the superbit DVD, its spot on. The audio on the DD track is surprisingly the preferred option over DTS in this particular case.
This movie brings fun and excitement, it has a great plot and very good actors, it is thrilling ,emotional and very enjoyable.
The professional actors and actress make the movie the best and the director done his best job in his career for this movie.

reviews.review_title: About the Plant... (Spoiler) (Remember the plant in the pot?)
reviews.content: OK, I loved this movie, really, totally. I got nervous with the "sexual tension" in the USA version, so I dunno about seeing the French version--but I'm pretty prudish so ignore me.BUT about the plant. Great allegory, bad choice of plant. I'm a biologist (and I guess a perfectionist too) so when I saw her put the plant in the ground, I immediately thought to myself:"That plant is never gonna make it."It was in the shade of an oak tree and it looked like a tropical-origin house plant that can't survive a freezing winter. Bummer. Kinda spoiled the ending for me. Silly but true.If that was the biggest problem, then you know it was a great movie.

reviews.review_title: Stop #2 Into The Mind Of Besson
reviews.content: This was my 2nd stop (or first if you don't count Fifth Element) into the world of Luc Besson, and it is one of the few films I have seen that I sat in awe right through the credits (some of the others being Hero and Fight Club). Everything about this film was done to perfection, the direction, the acting, it was all done with such passion! Jean Reno is as always phenomenal, yet again he slips seamlessly into character so well you can't attach any other role to him, and the emotion he conveys is so real it really plays on the heart strings. Nathalie Portman is superb, better than a lot of actors twice her age and the chemistry between the two makes it feel more like a real life than a film. This film has faced a lot of opposition in the past for its supposed paedophillic undertones, and to that i say b*ll***s, watch the film, you will understand in ways that i fail to find the words to convey how beautiful the relationship between Leon and Mathilda really is. Luc Besson has a way of bringing me to tears, it happened in Big Blue and it happened in this.I cannot help but give this 10/10, it has jumped straight to the top of my favourite films list, and will be a hard one to shift, if you are thinking of passing this by i urge you to reconsider, you will regret it! stay tuned for my next trip into the world of Besson Le Dernier Combat

I simply cannot express in words how amazing this movie is. Besides, hundreds of other people have already chronicled its nearly unparalleled appeal. Instead I have the following observations: I must say that when I first saw the U.S. release, "The Professional", on the big screen in 1994 I was not as adamant about its allure. I felt it was an intelligent action movie (which is generally an oxymoron, especially for Hollywood) with an excellent cast and a good story, but lacked the character development necessary to make it truly great. However, the more recent DVD release of the international version, "Leon", has glued together the holes and turned a great action film into a veritable masterpiece. The humanistic elements of this story, especially the interaction between the two protagonists (Portman and Reno) leaves the viewer no choice but to feel sympathy and compassion for their plight. This is quite uncommon in film.I cannot believe it got no Academy attention whatsoever (actually it's not so hard to believe with all the politics that go into the choices). I will say that 1994 was an excellent year for film...a year in which the Academy Award winner "Forrest Gump" was probably the fourth best film behind this one, "The Shawshank Redemption", and "Pulp Fiction".Anyway, take my word for it. You must see this movie. It is violent but the violence is simply the hard shell around the fruit that's inside. Crack it open and have a look. You won't be disappointed!

reviews.review_title: Leon the hard but soft heart killer. It's a masterpiece!
reviews.content: Luc Besson is a super talented producer: he succeeded in engaging his audience either with a VERY positive or a SUPER negative responses. He could make us see compassion in a merciless hit-man (Leon) and at the same time, he could engage rage on account of a roaming free ruthless criminal and a no-age boundary romance. He led his viewers see that a deviant behavior CAN be a product of society's injustice. Loss of response to death and killing other people can be a survival mode of a deeply hidden broken heart. Aileen, the woman serial killer, didn't she also experience serious injustice? Both Mathilda and Leon experienced mistreatment and emotional destruction that led both of them in some way behave the way they do. The beating that Mathilda suffered and her very unloving family background made her heart even bitter and become emotionless to death at her early age. She became too mature for her age. Luc Besson combined reality with myth. Part of the romance in the story is possible, but in some way, the super rapidity of the hit-man can be doubted. The sexual awakening behavior of a pre-adolescent girl is very much a reality. Her attraction to an older man that can portray her missed normal relationship with her own abusive father is a reality. As for Leon, he has an emotional level of a 19 year old who was badly struck by his first love morbid experience despite the fact that he is much much older. He lost the capacity to love and respond to love as if his own heart is dead some twenty years ago. Leon portrays a dead heart person that could not feel any pity any longer to taking other's lives as a result of his incapability to face lost love. He chose death and killing as his sole purpose for life. Both Leon and Mathilda's love awake in this movie. The movie looks at the emotional dynamism rather than the morals of the hypocritical society. Luc Besson denounces the societal structure that often is at the root of society's illnesses. Gary Oldman, Mathilda's parents and Leon's former girlfriend's dad were the ones to blame. Leon and Mathilda are the victims. This is a great movie because it made its point whatever where you stand. The meaning is deeper and commends reflection and serious analysis. The fatal end is sad but triumphant since Leon "lived" again. He could love and forget his gloomy past, and especially, he made the unloved little girl, Mathilda emotionally happy and economically secure. At least, Mathilda is ready for life, she has been loved. How pitiful for those who have never been loved. Yes, Leon, what a "Killer"!Luc Besson, congratulations!

reviews.review_title: Absorbing, emotional, Intense, exciting and tragic.
reviews.content: Interpreted as an action film, Leon includes some of the most exciting and memorable shootout scenes in cinema. Leon, the professional, becomes the epitome of 'cool' by his use of guns and fighting techniques, all realistically portrayed in some frantic shootots. However, Leon is not simply some dumb action flick, but rather an exploration of character relationships, police corruption and, ultimately, doomed love.Jean Reno plays Leon, a withdrawn and silent hit-man, drawn into the depths of police corruption, brutality and evil by the helpless Matilda, played by a young Natalie Portman. Gary Oldman plays the ruthless and corrupted cop Norman Stansfield, who slaughters Matilda's family, and becomes narcotically obsessed with finding Leon. All three main characters excel in their roles, especially Gary Oldman, who portrays the evil and corrupt lawman as well as anyone ever has in cinema history. Jean Reno massively improves over his great cameo appearance in 'Nikita', and Natalie Portman sets her own stage for a future career. Overall, Leon is a beautifully crafted and excellent film, and i would give it a fantastic 9 out of 10.

This movie was outstanding in a multitude of ways. Natalie Portman delivered her best performance, this being said after seeing V for Vendetta. Jean Reno is also wonderful, as the relationship of his character, Leon and Portman's character, Mathilda takes center stage. The story line and writing are great, but the acting and multi-layered dialog between Reno and Portman are what elevate the movie. The hit-man missions and big explosions are executed with excellence, but only serve as a backdrop for this movie, which at its core is a character/ relationship development piece. Mathilda, the oh-so mature and hardened 12 year old needs Leon as a role model, just as Leon needs Mathilda to essentially learn how to live life. The relationship there is truly complex, fascinating, and believable thanks to superb acting and dialog that does a exceptional job of facilitating the relationship. The ending left a little to be wondered about, but this could possibly be intentional, and The Professional is still one of my favorites.

I have to say, after watching "Léon" countless times in the past, it never ceases to amaze me. There is a certain simplistic beauty in the shots, in the characters, and in the story. Léon, the title character, is a 'cleaner' who lives modestly in his apartment on the same floor as Mathilda (a young and endearing Natalie Portman), a pre-teen with a bad family life. When the slightly-unhinged, corrupt law enforcer Norman Stansfield (perfectly played by Gary Oldman) shows up and murders Mathilda's family, she has no choice but to seek help with her neighbor.And from there the story takes off; a bond slowly grows between Mathilda and Léon, and it all winds down to a heart-wrenching final scene. I just love this movie. Bravo, Luc Besson.(note: I suggest you watch "Léon" rather than the edited "The Professional." The former goes into much more detail in the relationship of the two main characters, and reveals more about their time together.)

reviews.review_title: European cinema at its best, blended with American action
reviews.content: French cinema has arguably been the best since the days of Les Jeux Interdits.  I have been getting very weary of American patriotism and hyped up action-oozing drivel from across the Atlantic.  Enter Luc Besson with a truly engaging portrait of a killer (Jean Reno) for hire.  A killer whose only friend is a plant which he looks after with more than a little care. Natalie Portman in her first film is extraordinary.  Gary Oldman is outstanding as a drug crazed cop. Some have said that it is yet another action film.  I say, scratch beneath the surface to reveal an utterly outstanding piece of cinema.  I've found nothing to match it.

The cast under brilliant direction and a subtly haunting soundtrack make this movie a masterpiece. Casting Portman and Reno together, young and hasty with patient and calm. They are opposites that complete each other. Oldman as the fiend is excellent, it seems playing the demented villan is his forte`.The soundtrack which is very European and sets a sad and melencholly tune that some how hints the whole movie that things appeare to be to good to be true.All the characters are conflicts. Non seem to be how they appear anitially. The cold and calculating assassin turns out to have a heart. The cocky self assured little girl finds out she needs love to survive.
This movie is one of the heart and the human condition. Beson shows how people in any extra-ordinary circumstance still need love, company and meaning.Beson is excellent in the way he makes things seem not as they look. In the end a great movie with action and something to think about.Rating ***** out of *****

reviews.review_title: I long to see the version integral
reviews.content: Growing up in England, European cinema was an intriguing alternative to the home-grown fare and the imported (mainly US) staple.  I'm not quite sure when I became a convert to the European narrative, but Luc Besson was an integral part.  My infatuation with Nikita has waned, (but please don't watch Point of No Return as an alternative (though Bridget Fonda will remain a favourite), or Nikita dubbed) we are not discussing alternatives.Luc Besson's relationship with Jean Reno is essential, from the early role as the drummer in Subway, to Reno's position as the ultimate European hitman.Leon provides Jean Reno ample space to prove himself the icy hardman, but it is his relationship with the then 12 year old Natalie Portman, Matilda, that provides him the opportunity to express the paternal side to his ice-cool hitman that completes his charactarisation.The often taunted "Version Integral", only currently available on R2 Japanese import, adds a further 20 minutes to the development of Matilda's relationship with Leon, and I for one can't wait for my chance to see it.This is for me currently the best action film available.

reviews.review_title: A great film and Luc Bessons best
reviews.content: #Very slight spoiler#(If evan that)If you watched the action filled trailer prior to viewing the movie don't expect a action film as suggested by the that said trailer. While the action set pieces are brilliant, Besson focuses on the relationship between a lonely hitman (Jean Reno) and a young girl (Natalie Portman) who lives next door. when a bent cop (Gary Oldman) murders the girl's family, the hitman takes the young girl under his wing. The performances by the lead cast are wonderful. Jean Reno is very believable as a lonely hitman giving a very emotional performance. Natalie Portman and Gary Oldman are also brilliant in career best performances. Gary Oldmans psycho cop is extremely entertaining to watch. Luc Bessons direction must be mentioned, simply because it is excellent. The emotional scenes are handled well and the action scenes rival anything in a big budget Hollywood production (especially the Leon vs the swat team scene). Overall this is an exciting piece of European cinema (though it is filmed in America, the style remains French).9 out of 10

It does not turn childish and cute as one may think. It is not another cliché film where the bad guy is turned to good by the love of a child. It combines the comic relationship between Leon (Reno) and Mathilda (Portman) with emotional tradgedies of Mathildas past and yet does no lose any of the action and excitement that Gary Oldman's character Stansfield throws into the mix. A truly great film.

reviews.review_title: Perhaps that held back the film a bit at the time.

His neighbor, 12-year-old Matilda (Natalie Portman), has an abusive father (Michael Badalucco) who trades drugs for Stansfield (Gary Oldman). Stansfield deals with the family. She returns home and finds Stansfield's men there. She pretends and goes to Leon. It turns out that these are corrupt DEA agents. Janitor Leon reluctantly lets her in and she asks him to teach her a lesson. She wants revenge on the killers of his younger brother.Director Luc Besson brings his frequent collaborator Jean Reno to America and makes a pleasant discovery with a young Natalie Portman. Before Hit Girl, there was Matilda. Gary Oldman is an excellent weird villain. Luc Besson has a certain French flair for his actions. He has a really unique take on the action thriller genre. He definitely has an aggressive style that sometimes sexualizes the young Portman. She shows many adult inclinations. Perhaps that held back the film a bit at the time.

reviews.review_title: Not just a film- a work of art
reviews.content:
Luc Besson has captured the true art of film making in Leon. Not just in the direction of the film but the writing of it."Leon" tells the tale of a hitman working and living in New York City. Leon, the title character (played by Jean Reno), isn't just a hitman, he is the best hitman in the city. He has nothing to live for really, he just works. His life changes when he is given the responsibility of taking care of a young girl, Mathilda (played by a young Natalie Portman), after her family is killed by a psychotic DEA officer named Norman Stansfield (Gary Oldman.) Mathilda immediately catches the attention of Leon after she thinks it's "cool" to be a hitman or "cleaner." She ask him to teach her the art of "cleaning" so she can have her revenge on the killer of her family.
The performance of Natalie Portman is the best in the movie considering she plays a 12 year-old girl in a strange situation. Jean Reno is also quite good as the quiet hitman but Gary Oldman was amazing! Always a bad guy, Oldman's twisted and scary performance blew me away.Some are bothered by the strange relationship between Leon and Mathilda but that is what you need to focus on to understand the film fully. Maybe for today's world it "pushed the envelope" a little (For example, in one scene, Leon and Mathilda share a bed.) But you have to look beyond the strange relationship to see the love behind it.10/10 in my book.

Jean Reno, Gary Oldman, and Natalie Portman in her first film, turn in sterling performances in a movie about death rebirth and love.Some may find the love relationship between Leon and Mathilda unnerving but this is not the crux of the story.  The story is not just about about Mathilda's sexual awakening.  She awakens into a loving relationship that is more than sexual.  Her previous father figure was abusive.  Leon rescues her from that existence and they both show each other what unconditional love realy means.It is also about Leon's emotional awaking through Mathilda.  Scarred from his first love relationship he has created a monochrome world where nothing exists but death.  Mathilda is his first taste of real life.  Mathilda awakens in him a longing for somehting more than his current existence.Ultimately this film is about hope.  Early in the movie Mathilda asks Leon "is it always this bad . . ."  In a somewhat cynical response he says yes. If you were to ask his character the same question at the  end of the movie he would probably say "No, even if only for a fleeting moment."Give this movie a look if nothing more than for the fine measured performances of several fine actors and an early look at an amazing your actress.

reviews.review_title: Leon A.K.A The Professional. this movie is one of 10 best of my lifetime.

In the cut version you never hear of the crippling by lost love in the past and the reason he finds new life in the commitment to care for the orphan and to live again but must compete with his past and present dilemmas. (at the time of the filming, she spoke 3 or more languages fluently, I don't remember exactly) as well as many other things I find amazing to her credit. Although ... living in a city with a daily theme of state court-cases against organised crime and outright 'murder-machinery' , laid out in detail by all forms of media - would you have thought of Amsterdam, Netherlands ?? - i have come to read several (semi-)biographical books ( - for my son's school exams -sic ! ) about the who, what, where, whens & whys , and hows , within our florishing underworld , more often than not with some sympathies and/or added 'human touches' ladled freely onto the various protagonists , mainly disenfranchised immigrant youths . A long introduction - i am aware of .
Now , to emphasize that i found my recent watching of "Leon" decidedly captivating , and the overwhelming number of aspects of Besson's direction ( or in short 'his movie' ) extremely well done - and most 'enjoyable' , well , 'entertaining' would be much the better term - i have nevertheless the following reservation : From the moment that Mathilde comes home to find her family murdered , no, even before - when she's sent out for an errant - you absolutely know the plot , all to the finish , with her returning to her school benches with the school mistress admonishing her not to fiddle with life's truths ....
It's all very well 'presented' cinematographically , but then 'we' are 'here' ever so spoiled by equally 'fantastic' detective series by BBC , ITV , and all & sundry European productions , many of them way past the usual Hollywood Mega-Money Crap . And then ,,, well , while i gladly admit that there is plenty of very professional good , even excellent acting throughout "Leon" , in particular the child Natalie Portman , and some of the supporting actors like the 'gorilla' coming to Leon's door , and of course our 'villain's' over-the-top performance make for good entertainment , but all said , the story's characters couldn't be more cliché if one tried : the casting of Leon is exactly to his role as Forrest Gump , and if you were looking for a 'nevertheless-sympathetic' Italian Crook , well , there you got 'im , nice acting , nicely presented , just what you would expect !!!
This is where , for me , the film fails . i do watch better actors five times a week , often better cast , and certainly in much better stories , mostly detectives like "Wallander" ( the Swedish production ) or "Montalbano" and more ... And i have not forgotten movies like "The Third Man" , "Face of Evil" , "From Here To Eternity" , "Tokio Ga" , "Woman In the Dunes" , "Badlands" a.s.o. - or "Gloria" ..
Notwithstanding "Leon" is a pretty good movie , worth one's time and attention , there are so many , many , many worse ones heaped upon us . Daily .

reviews.review_title: Turbulence, Romance and Ontology all in one...
reviews.content: A hitman with nothing to lose. A little girl with with everything lost. Two worlds collide, two beliefs clash, two lifestyles merge, and the result is LEON. What can I say? This is by far my favorite film and I'm not afraid to say so. Directed by Luc Besson, LEON has touched on so many thematic elements that are subtly concealed under the fascinating hollywood-like fighting sequence. From LEON, the viewer sees Luc's terrifying portrait of Devil incarnated in human flesh, of elegant mastermanship embodied in a contract killer with the mind of a child, of desperate innocence endowed in an "overgrown" child, of Love, of Family, of Care, and above all, of Sexuality. Can't say too much about the film or I'll spoil it, but I have a few words of advice. While watching it, please pay attention to every little detail that Luc Besson has enstaged for your satisfaction, as every little scene performs a specific, no matter how small, task. Secondly, please do not, and I beg with the greatest sincerity, limit your imagination. Let it run free and wild! And leave room for debates, for discussions, for back talks, as this film in no way ends with every question answered. The point is proven, but its shadow hovers on, encircling everyone who has watched and received an impact from it. I got mine, and even now, every moment I think about LEON, I feel a violent rumble running through my nerves, a painful revelation, a blissful remembrance. Hail to Luc Besson, this is no doubt one of his best films, and one of the precious gems out there that did not get tampered with even with all the actions that Luc has projected.

Spoilers ahead-- please watch the movie first before you read this review.I dimly remember watching the US version years ago, and that the effect it had on me surprised me, although I don't think I saw the whole movie. I watched the Uncut International version again in the past few days all the way through and the effect on me is even more astonishing.First of all, to put it into perspective, I'm a wife and mother of three under 11 with fairly conservative movie preferences. That's why it surprised me that this movie touched me. Would I have been offended if the character Leon had made sexual advances to the character Mathilda from the very beginning? Yes. Would I have been offended if the movie had depicted graphic sexual scenes? Definitely. But I think the director Luc Besson had not crossed that fine line, and the message he got to me was that this wasn't about pedophilia at all. For me, the most powerful impression I got from this movie was that it was about people who long for love and belonging and are unlikely to ever find them. Sure, Mathilda dresses seductively for her age, but if you consider her role models, her abusive family life, and her obsession with TV, and the fact that you will find teenagers her age in any American high school who speaks profanities and dresses just as skimpily, if not more so, than she is, then her character is understandable and recognizable. I feel compassion for her, for she is one of the thousands of girls in the world who may never find love or kindness if it doesn't find them. I realize that she may never have had a normal childhood, and went from twelve to twenty in mind if not in body. To me she symbolizes the little girl in every woman, the little girl who longs for love and protection-- but because of the harsh realities of life, gets only abuse and contempt. She's also the woman in every prepubescent girl who grows up too fast because of her circumstances. Natalie Portman's heartrending performance touched my heart as a mother and as a woman.Sure, the action sequences were nail bitingly taut. I like a good action movie myself. You sit wide-eyed and amazed at this hit-man who has never missed a kill, and who seems to move through the scene like an avenging ghost, swift and invisible. You also feel a sense of pity for a man whose choices in the past has doomed him to a life of death and isolation-- a man who has given up on love a long time ago and never expects it to come to him. He has a child-like character, with a grimly simple life-- all hard work and no play, all death and little laughter. He chooses not to have any women because of what happened to his girlfriend when he was young. And because he started his career as a hit-man at 19, his emotional growth has been stunted so that he remains the lost little boy that he had been at 19, perhaps feeling he has to pay for the rest of his life for the crime he had committed. And yet, despite being a hit man, to me he gave the impression that he was as honorable as a man in his circumstances could be-- more honorable than the abusive father, more than Tony, who eventually betrayed him, more than the corrupt federal officials who should have been otherwise. In the end, after he gave his life for Mathilda, I concluded that if my husband and I had been murdered, and my daughter faced a choice between a violent death, a life of fear and abuse, and being protected by this man-- well, is there really a choice? Jean Reno's performance is amazing.Many mentions have been made about Gary Oldman's performance and I have to agree that he makes a marvelously wacky bad guy. And this movie did make me laugh.

Leon, aka The Professional, is one of the best hit-man movies ever made. Collecting contracts never looked this cool but, there is much more to the story in Luc Besson's masterpiece.Leon (Jean Reno) is the best in the business. Cold, ruthless, with the ability to take out a 'client' before they even know they are in danger. In and out without a trace. With an unassuming look and somewhat gawky presentation to the outside world, no one would ever know that the person walking passed them on the sidewalk is carrying enough firepower to take out a small army in his briefcase. His life is simple, his surroundings are simple, his expectations are simple. The only items in his life he cannot leave behind are his love for milk and his plant.Matilda (Natalie Portman) is a 12 year old girl. Troubled by her family situation and wondering if life ever gets easier. Her father beats her, her mother could care less, and her sister takes closely after her mother. The only person that means anything to her is her brother, a 5 year old little boy who turns to Matilda when things get a little rough at home. This is the way things are, the way they have been all along. Things are about to change.When Matilda's entire family gets murdered by a ruthless FBI agent (Gary Oldman), Matilda turns to Leon for help. Unwillingly, Leon takes the girl in and soon the girl is exposed to what this quiet man down the hall does for a living, collecting contracts. Matilda immediately wants to learn the business and take revenge for her murdered brother. (Taking a .38 and firing out the window of Leon's apartment to make her point.) Leon, again unwillingly, begins to teach the girl how the business works and the rules that professionals must follow. No women, no kids.This is a truly amazing story that takes you on a journey of mixed emotions. There are scenes that will make you uncomfortable, scenes that will make you cheer, and scenes that will make you think.

"You've given me a taste for life". This movie is about an empty man who becomes filled with passion. The awkward conversations and sleek action scenes provide a humorous and violent movie, teeming with character development. From the outset we realise that Leon is an excellent assassin, methodical and controlled. This seems like a recipe for an average action film, like so many before this one. Leon's skill is shown in the violent scenes of the film. He kills with such ease and sleek class that it makes one squirm with gratuitous pleasure, similar to the effect felt watching the likes of a good James Bond. Films of this nature, typically bursting with sex and glamorised violence, seldom touch as deeply on the isolation that fills these contract killers' time as 'Leon: The Professional".The reason behind his proficiency for killing, and the ability to deal with the additional psychological weight, is due to his lack of humanity. In this sense, the film goes against the stream of conventional action movies about hit men. Leon sleeps sitting up, drinks only milk and his apartment lacks furniture. Even the bare apartment has more character than Leon, a man of few words with a seemingly emotionless and unsophisticated personality. Leon's zest for creativity and love for living is deficient. Even his language is sparse. These qualities are what we like to think makes us human, our creativity and language. This is made more evident when contrasting him to Gary Oldman's spectacular character. Leon has no personal gain or purpose for his killing, he has no need for the money he makes from it, but Oldman is driven by greed and desperation. Oldman provides a great performance as the 'bad guy'. His psychotic unpredictability and restless facial contortions are absolutely terrifying. His brief composure when listening to classical music provides a great juxtaposition to his unstable, violent and torturous persona. This eccentric performance probably influenced Dafoe's character of an unstable cop in 'The Boondock Saints'. Matilda brings light and excitement into Leon's life. She has an inspiring ability to surprise the audience with her maturity. Throughout the film I found myself questioning her real age due to her direct language and confidence, something that is a stark contrast to Leon's unassuming and frankly wooden persona. This is where the movie shines. Allowing yourself to temporarily forget her age and the limitations that boundary entails brings forth a powerful relationship between the two protagonists in which they both learn from each other. For Matilda she wants to be accepted and treated as an adult and for Leon, he wishes to feel alive again, even if he does not know it. Matilda's love cannot be taken lightly, as despite her age, she is more emotionally aware than Leon. Because they never kiss, their relationship is shrouded in uncertainty. Matilda's language is passionate and I look upon as genuine love. Whether it is romantic or not is up to you, however the knot in her stomach that disappears makes me personally lean towards the former. There are times when Leon is both a father figure and lover to Matilda, and the film works well by leaving the audience forever hanging in suspicion. Their relationship is no doubt powerful and the way both characters grow beside each other is blindingly obvious but romantic.The effect Matilda and Leon have on each other is astounding and powerful. Leon, the ultimate professional, begins making mistakes. He now has things worth living for and spending money on, and the humanity we have never seen in Leon increases. Matilda's confidence grows around Leon. Perhaps she feeds off his social ineptitude and quiet demeanour and uses his silence to fuel her words. Nevertheless, at the end we realise that the limitation of age is stronger than the lie she has been living. The whole fantasy brutally spirals back to reality. Without Leon she is still a young girl. Leon's quest for passion arcs in a full circle at the end of the film with him returning to his childhood. His first kill at 19 was for love, as was his last. Whether it romantic or paternal love, you decide.The film brings forth the poignant question: who decides who should fall in love? 'Leon: The Professional' echoes with themes similar to 'Romeo and Juliet' and 'Lolita', should society define who can fall in love? Whether it age or social class, love is not a force to place boundaries on.

Every aspect of the movie delivers to the audience and makes an impressive overall package. Jean Reno plays a character named Léon who has learned to repress his emotions in order to perform his job as a "cleaner", or hit-man. His secluded world is shattered by the young girl named Mathilda who lives on the same floor as he does in an apartment building. When she turns to him for help, he learns about living a normal life, even if the circumstances which unite them are far from normal.The performance delivered by then twelve-year old Natalie Portman as Mathilda is nothing short of brilliant. Her ability to relate to others with body movement and facial gestures is matched by few, she really brings raw emotion and believability to a difficult role. Mathilda and Léon are unexpectedly thrown together, but learn to value life from their chance encounter, and how valuable a friendship can be.Jean Reno as Léon gives us a solemn and calculated character who sets all of his energy on his assignments until her is given something else to care about. Mathilda gives him the daughter that he never had, while Léon serves as a father and friend to her. Gary Oldman, as the corrupt DEA Agent Norman Stansfield, offers the viewers an amazingly wired and electrical performance which pushes the envelope. He moves the story along by his actions. Oldman offers us a memorable portrait of a sadistically obsessed man who stops short of nothing to get what he wants.The Professional is what movie-making is all about. Without the overuse of special effects, a large shooting location, or a commercially star studded cast, we are given all that could possibly be asked for in a movie. Portman, Oldman, and Reno, along with Danny Aiello as the hit- contractor Tony remind us that there is no substitute for great acting. There are elements of comedy, drama, and action, and great original

reviews.review_title: Léon (in U.S. and Canada, The Professional)
reviews.content: Luc Besson has been justifiably accused of valorizing style over content, and The Professional is a minor stylistic masterpiece. The psychological realism of the script is in continual tension with the recurring wide-angle and long-perspective camera. Faces are examined in extreme close-up or from below, and the camera is often aimed down the long, narrow corridors of interior architecture (the scene in Mathilda's apartment when she's gone to buy milk, for example, or in the mens' room of a government building when she is confronting a villain). This is New York--and American movie culture--as seen through the eyes of a European artist, and Besson's vision performs the interesting task of familiarizing the good old North American version of a crime thriller. Jean Reno is suitably semi-opaque as Léon, and Natalie Portman is utterly mesmerizing as Mathilda in her film debut. Gary Oldman is Gary Oldman: not an inch of scenery goes unchewed. (See also La Femme Nikita for the prequel to Léon's character.

This is movie is truly incredible. This movie grabs you right from the start and keeps you on edge to the very end. It's shockingly blunt at times and would be nothing short of disturbing if not for clever words and brilliant performances by Jean Reno and Natalie Portman who somehow connect with your heart and make it easy to relate and feel for the impossibly complicated and complex characters and situations. The movie has a flair all of its own, a sense of dark coolness and colorful adolescence combined with an air of freedom that make for an unforgettable contrast. This is one of those movies that after watching will leave you in awe of how smart and unique it is. Watch it you wont be disappointed. Incredible.

Léon is a very fun movie, with an outstanding performance from the young Nathalie Portman. The balance of its strange sence of humour, the abnormal romance, the young girl committing crimes and of course the presence of all the action makes the movie great to watch not only at fridaynight.However my experience with watching this film was that it made mee feel a little uncomfortable with its structure. The 'first part', as what I am referring to as the part from the very beginning untill Mathilda knocks on Léons door, the movie seemed like an ironic actionmovie with strange but great scenes. This was unexpected because people would expect a serious relationship coming up between Léon and Mathilda.That's why there is the 2nd part. The part the movie get's more serious in any way. You see Mathilda and Léon growing an relationship, there's only a little doubt whether it's a father and doughter relationship or it's just love between those two. In the 3rd part, where we actually see them really loving each other, wich was kind of expected, the movie feels like just another romantic movie with a guy who cannot love anymore...At the grand finale the movie made clear it came straight from hollywood. The overuse of explosions, and just action in general. The unrealistic (almost) surviving of Léon and the killing of the villain at the end is a real anticlimax for the film. At first, everything seemed funny and ironic. Then it became serious because there was an interesting relationship going on, but the unrealistic end destroys the rest of the movie.One thing you can't discuss is the stunning acting from Portman troughout the film. There are loads of ways to the describe it but there is no way to do that negatively. On the other hand I think Reno played a little boring role. He needed to be a cold killer because of his merciless past. I get it he had to play a feelingless man and he did it well. I just don't think he was the right man to play it. Here's why: People like him, people with a traumatic and unforgivable past, should indeed be acting like that and should indeed have a face like that but, you should read their former pain in their eyes, and I don't think I have really seen it in the eyes of Jean Reno. He did feel emotionless, but it felt like that for almost the whole movie wich is a little boring. The mysterious eyes from someone else would have made the character have a little more depth.
Léon is a mix between a comedy, a romantic drama and an artificial action movie. But none of it really dominates the movie so it is in that way a unique movie. Just with a little anticlimax.

After seeing Leon for the first time i was amazed, mainly because a film this good had not been that well known. If you enjoy action, drama, and the odd emotional roller-coaster this is definitely one for you! This is quite possibly Luc Besson's greatest work. Jean Renno is superb as Leon, and Natalie Portman does an excellent job as supporting actress, Mathilda. There is an excellent performance from the renowned Gary Oldman, since watching this film for the first time i began to watch more and more of Gary Oldman's work. He is an acting genius.Leon is the story of a reclusive hit-man who finds contempt and a greater lust for life in a 12 year old girl, Mathilda.
My personal favourite. Have seen this movie countless times and will watch it again. Great action, memorable characters and overall an interesting movie to watch.

reviews.review_title: I think Luc Besson created a chef-d'oeuvre
reviews.content: This is a wonderful film with unpredictable plot line, which reveals the consequences of sadism, withdrawal and isolation from society. To be honest , I think this film is a representation of an incredible performance by Gary Oldman. His role of DEA agent with narcotic addiction, that eventually leads him to an absolute madness, makes film extremely tense, and every second you feel either like the cleaner or agent.
